speaker: SAMPSON
content: Sampson declares that he and Gregory will not endure insults or mistreatment. "Carry coals" was an idiom meaning to put up with abuse or humiliation. He is asserting that they will defend their pride and not be disrespected.

speaker: GREGORY
content: Gregory is punning on the word "colliers," which means coal miners. He jokes that if they were moved to anger by an insult, they would be "colliers"—a dirty, low-class profession—playing on the idea of being "collared" or controlled. He means they should remain calm and not let the Montagues provoke them.

speaker: SAMPSON
content: Sampson says that if they become angry ("in choler"), they will draw their swords. This shows his readiness to fight and his aggressive loyalty to the Capulet household.

speaker: GREGORY
content: Gregory is telling Sampson to avoid trouble or responsibility—"draw your neck out o’ the collar" means to pull your head out of a yoke, like an ox avoiding work. He is essentially saying: stay out of trouble while you can.

speaker: SAMPSON
content: Sampson claims he is quick to fight when provoked. He is boasting about his aggressive nature and readiness to respond to any insult.

speaker: GREGORY
content: Gregory is teasing Sampson by saying he is slow to start a fight. He implies that Sampson is reluctant or cowardly when it comes to drawing his sword.

speaker: SAMPSON
content: Sampson means that a Montague servant is provoking him. He uses "dog" as an insult to show contempt for his enemy.

speaker: GREGORY
content: Gregory plays with the double meaning of "moved"—both physically stirred and emotionally provoked. He jokes that if Sampson is "moved" (angered), he will run away, twisting the idea of valor into cowardice.

speaker: SAMPSON
content: Sampson claims that even a dog from the Montague household would provoke him to stand his ground. He insists he will force any Montague, man or woman, to walk in the gutter while he takes the better, cleaner path near the wall.

speaker: GREGORY
content: Gregory is insulting Sampson by calling him a weak servant. The phrase "the weakest goes to the wall" means that the weakest person is pushed aside or defeated.

speaker: SAMPSON
content: Sampson claims that women are physically weaker ("weaker vessels") and thus always pushed aside or dominated. He then applies this crude logic to his feud with the Montagues, boasting that he will push their men aside in a fight and sexually assault their women.

speaker: GREGORY
content: Gregory says the feud is between their masters, the Capulets and Montagues, but it extends to their servants as well. This means the servants are also expected to fight and take sides in the conflict.

speaker: SAMPSON
content: Sampson is boasting that he will act like a tyrant by fighting the men of the rival Montague house. His threat to "be civil with the maids" and "cut off their heads" is a crude sexual pun, meaning he will take the women's virginity.

speaker: GREGORY
content:
Gregory is twisting Sampson's crude joke about taking the "maidenheads" (virginity) of Montague women.  
He deliberately misinterprets "maidenheads" as literal heads, making a dark pun about violence against women.

speaker: SAMPSON
content: Sampson makes a crude pun on "heads," suggesting he will either cut off the heads of the Montague women or take their virginity ("maidenheads"). He is boasting about violence and sexual aggression, leaving the interpretation deliberately provocative.

speaker: GREGORY
content: Gregory means that only those who are physically struck will understand the insult. In other words, the pain of the blow will make the meaning clear to them.

speaker: SAMPSON
content: Sampson boasts that he will fight anyone as long as he is physically able to stand. He adds that he is well-known for being a strong and capable man.

speaker: GREGORY
content: Gregory is insulting Sampson by saying if he were a fish, he would be a "poor John"—a cheap, dried fish considered low-quality. He then tells Sampson to draw his sword because members of the rival Montague family are approaching.

speaker: SAMPSON
content: Sampson is telling Gregory he has drawn his sword — "naked weapon" — and is ready for a fight. He promises to support Gregory if he starts a quarrel.

speaker: GREGORY
content: Gregory is mocking the idea of cowardice. He sarcastically suggests that the only way to "turn" and "run" would be if a Montague man provoked him by showing disrespect.

speaker: SAMPSON
content: Sampson is assuring his companion Gregory that he can be trusted to be bold and not back down in a fight. This shows his eagerness to prove his courage and loyalty to the Capulet household.

speaker: GREGORY
content: Gregory sarcastically says "No, truly" ("marry" is a mild oath) and pretends to be afraid of his friend Sampson. This is playful banter between the two Capulet servants, showing their camaraderie as they provoke the Montagues.

speaker: SAMPSON
content: Sampson suggests that he and Gregory should wait for the Montagues to strike first so that they can claim self-defense under the law. This way, they can fight without being held legally responsible for starting the brawl.

speaker: GREGORY
content: Gregory says he will scowl at the Montague servants as he walks past, and they can interpret his expression however they wish. This shows his readiness to provoke a fight while pretending innocence.

speaker: SAMPSON
content: Biting one's thumb is an insulting gesture, like flipping someone off today. Sampson is saying he will provoke the Montague servants, and it will be shameful for them if they do not respond to the insult.

speaker: ABRAM
content: Abram is asking if the other man is making an insulting gesture at him and his companions. To "bite your thumb" was a rude and provocative sign of disrespect, similar to a modern obscene gesture.

speaker: SAMPSON
content: Biting one's thumb was a rude, insulting gesture, similar to flipping someone off today. Sampson is deliberately provoking the Montague servants to start a fight.

speaker: ABRAM
content: Biting your thumb was a rude, insulting gesture, similar to flipping someone off today. Abram is directly challenging the other man, asking if he is intentionally disrespecting him and his companions.

speaker: SAMPSON
content: Sampson is asking Gregory whether the law will support them if he starts a fight. He wants to know if he can claim self-defense and be legally justified.

speaker: GREGORY
content: Gregory is bluntly refusing to do something, likely continuing a quarrelsome exchange with his fellow servant Sampson. This single word reinforces the scene's aggressive, confrontational mood and the servants' eagerness to provoke a fight.

speaker: SAMPSON
content: Sampson is pretending to be polite while deliberately insulting the Montague servants. To "bite the thumb" was a rude,挑衅ing gesture, and by doing it while denying it was aimed at them, he is trying to provoke a fight.

speaker: GREGORY
content: Gregory is asking the man if he is looking for a fight. This question is a direct challenge, meant to provoke the other party and continue the public bickering between the Capulets and Montagues.

speaker: ABRAM
content: Abram denies wanting to fight. His polite but firm repetition of "sir" shows he is being respectful to the speaker, yet he is also standing his ground.

speaker: SAMPSON
content: Sampson is saying that if the Montague servant wants to fight, he is ready. He claims his master, the Capulet, is just as noble as the Montague's master, establishing the feud's basis in family honor.

speaker: ABRAM
content: Abram is saying he is not better than Sampson—meaning he is of equal status and will not yield or show deference. This defiant reply continues the servants' quarrel and shows their readiness to fight.

speaker: SAMPSON
content: Sampson is responding to his fellow servant Gregory, who has just spoken. His words show he is ready to follow his companion's lead in the conversation or the impending confrontation with the Montagues.

speaker: GREGORY
content: Gregory corrects Sampson's crude remark, telling him to "say better" or speak more appropriately. He then alerts Sampson that a relative of their master, the Capulets, is approaching, signaling they should be more careful with their words.

speaker: SAMPSON
content:
Sampson is saying he will do better than just "draw" his sword — he will actually use it against the Montague men.  
He is boasting to his companion Gregory, showing his eagerness to fight and prove his loyalty to the Capulets.

speaker: ABRAM
content: Abram bluntly accuses Sampson of lying to his face. This direct challenge escalates their verbal confrontation into a physical brawl, immediately establishing the violent tension between the Montague and Capulet households.

speaker: SAMPSON
content: Sampson challenges the Montagues to fight, telling them to draw their swords if they are truly brave men. He then reminds his companion Gregory to strike hard with his sword, calling it his "washing blow"—a metaphor for a forceful, sweeping strike meant to cleanly cut down his opponent.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: Benvolio is trying to stop the fight between the servants, calling them "fools" for their reckless violence. His command, "you know not what you do," suggests their brawl is senseless and dangerous, with consequences they fail to understand.

speaker: TYBALT
content: Tybalt insults Benvolio's companions as cowardly peasants, or "heartless hinds." He then commands Benvolio to face him, threatening that by doing so, Benvolio will be looking at the person who is about to kill him.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: Benvolio is telling Tybalt that he is only trying to stop the fight, not join it. He commands Tybalt to put his sword away or, if he must use it, to help him separate the brawling men.

speaker: TYBALT
content: Tybalt expresses his contempt for peace, declaring he hates the word as intensely as he hates hell, all Montagues, and the person he is addressing. He then immediately challenges his opponent to fight, calling him a coward.

speaker: FIRST CITIZEN
content: The First Citizen is rallying the townspeople to join the brawl, calling for them to arm themselves with clubs and spears to attack the feuding families. His cries to "beat them down" and target both houses show the public's frustration and how the noble families' quarrel has violently disrupted the entire city.

speaker: CAPULET
content: Capulet is demanding his long sword, a heavy two-handed weapon used by older men. He is calling for it to join the brawl, showing he is just as quick-tempered and eager to fight as the younger men.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
content: She is mocking her elderly husband for calling for a sword, implying he is too old and feeble to fight and should instead be using a crutch. Her words highlight the absurdity of the old men's feud and the generational divide in the conflict.

speaker: CAPULET
content: Capulet is calling for his sword because he sees his enemy Montague approaching. Montague is waving his sword in a show of defiance, which Capulet interprets as a personal insult.

speaker: MONTAGUE
content: Montague is addressing Lord Capulet directly, calling him a villain to insult him. He is being physically restrained, likely by his allies, and demands to be released so he can fight.

speaker: LADY MONTAGUE
content: Lady Montague is ordering her husband to stay where he is and not go looking for a fight with the Capulets. She is trying to prevent further violence from erupting in the streets.

speaker: PRINCE
content: The Prince angrily commands the brawling men to drop their weapons, calling them beasts for fighting until they bleed. He reveals this is the third recent street fight caused by the Capulet and Montague feud, which has even forced elderly citizens to take up arms. He issues an ultimatum: further public violence will be punished by death, then orders the crowds to disperse while summoning the feuding lords for a formal hearing.

speaker: MONTAGUE
content: Montague asks who has revived this long-standing feud. He then addresses his nephew Benvolio directly, asking if he was present when the latest fight broke out.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: Benvolio explains that he tried to break up a fight between the Montague and Capulet servants, but Tybalt arrived and immediately challenged him. Tybalt swung his sword aggressively but harmlessly—"cut the winds"—showing his hot-headedness. The brawl then escalated as more people joined until the Prince arrived to stop everyone.

speaker: LADY MONTAGUE
content: Lady Montague is asking if anyone has seen her son Romeo today. She is relieved that he was not present during the recent street brawl between the Montagues and Capulets.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: Benvolio tells Lady Montague that he saw her son Romeo at dawn, walking alone under a sycamore grove outside the city. When Romeo noticed Benvolio, he slipped away into the woods; Benvolio, recognizing that Romeo wanted solitude just as he himself sometimes did, respected his wish and did not follow.

speaker: MONTAGUE
content: Montague describes his son Romeo’s recent behavior: he has been seen crying and sighing heavily in the early morning, but as soon as the sun rises, he retreats to his room, shutting out daylight to create a self-imposed darkness. Montague worries this gloomy mood is a bad omen unless someone can find out what is troubling him and offer helpful advice.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: Benvolio asks his uncle, Lord Montague, if he knows what started the recent street brawl between the Montague and Capulet servants. This question establishes Benvolio as a peace-seeking character trying to understand the conflict rather than escalate it.

speaker: MONTAGUE
content: Montague is saying he does not know the reason for his son Romeo’s recent sadness, and he has been unable to find out from Romeo himself. This highlights Romeo’s withdrawn behavior and his father’s concern.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: Benvolio asks whether Romeo's friends have tried every possible way to urge him to explain his sadness. "Importun'd" means persistently asked or urged, and "by any means" suggests they should have tried all methods.

speaker: MONTAGUE
content: Montague says that Romeo keeps his feelings to himself and is so secretive that no one can figure out what is wrong. He compares Romeo to a flower bud eaten by a worm before it can bloom, suggesting his sadness is destroying him from within. Montague wishes he could find the cause of Romeo’s sorrow so he could help him.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: Benvolio is telling Montague and Lady Montague to step away so he can speak to Romeo alone. He will either learn what is troubling Romeo or be firmly refused.

speaker: MONTAGUE
content: Montague is telling Benvolio he hopes he will be fortunate enough to hear a truthful confession from Romeo. He then tells his wife they should leave, allowing Benvolio to speak with Romeo privately.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: Benvolio is greeting his cousin Romeo with "Good morrow," which simply means "Good morning." This polite, peaceful address contrasts with the violent public brawl that has just occurred, immediately establishing Benvolio's character as a calm and courteous figure.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo is surprised that it is still morning. He feels that time is passing slowly because he is so miserable.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: Benvolio says it has just struck nine o'clock in the morning. This detail emphasizes how early in the day the street brawl is taking place, showing the Capulets and Montagues are quick to fight.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo is complaining that time passes slowly when he is unhappy. He then asks if the person who just hurried away was his father.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: Benvolio confirms that he saw Romeo earlier. He asks why Romeo's time seems to be dragging—meaning he wants to know the cause of his friend's obvious melancholy and unhappiness.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo means that without the thing that would make time pass quickly, his hours feel long and tedious. He is referring to love—specifically, being in love—which makes time fly.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: Benvolio is asking whether Romeo is suffering from the pangs of love. This question introduces the central theme of Romeo's romantic melancholy and his infatuation with Rosaline at the start of the play.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo is responding to Benvolio's question about who he loves. He simply says "Out" to mean "Out of her favor" — she does not return his affection. This one word captures his despair over Rosaline's rejection.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: Benvolio is asking if Romeo’s sadness is caused by love. This question introduces the central theme of love and sets up Romeo’s forthcoming confession about his unrequited feelings for Rosaline.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo is saying that the woman he loves does not return his affection. He is "out of her favour," meaning she does not approve of or accept his love.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: Benvolio is saying that love appears gentle and appealing when you first see it, but in reality it proves to be harsh and oppressive. He contrasts the idealized view of love with its painful actual experience.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo complains that Cupid, who is traditionally blindfolded, still manages to find ways to make people fall in love against their will. He then expresses his own conflicted feelings about love through a series of paradoxes—such as "heavy lightness" and "cold fire"—to show how love feels both painful and unreal to him, leaving him emotionally confused.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: Benvolio is saying he feels more like crying than smiling. He is responding to Romeo's earlier question about whether he is laughing, and his sorrowful mood contrasts with Romeo's lovesick melancholy.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo is asking his friend Benvolio to clarify what he means by "good heart." He wants to know what specific situation or action Benvolio is referring to with that phrase.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: Benvolio is expressing sympathy for Romeo's emotional distress. He says he is grieving because of the suffering of Romeo's good heart.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo is saying that his own sorrows already weigh on him, and Benvolio's sympathy will only add more grief to his burden. He then describes love as a contradictory force: it begins as smoky sighs, then becomes a bright fire in lovers' eyes, but when troubled, it turns into a sea of tears. Ultimately, he calls love a form of discreet madness—both bitter poison and life-giving sweetness.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: Benvolio is telling Romeo to wait for him — "Soft!" means "Wait a moment!" — and insists that if Romeo leaves him behind, it would be treating him unfairly. This shows Benvolio’s loyalty and his determination to stay with his troubled friend.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo feels so emotionally distraught that he no longer recognizes himself. He is saying that his true self is absent, and the person speaking is a stranger.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: "Sadness" here means seriously or in earnest. Benvolio is asking Romeo to tell him honestly who he is in love with.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo is sarcastically asking if he should moan dramatically and then explain his feelings. He is mocking the conventional way lovers complain about their sorrows.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: Benvolio is asking Romeo to stop sighing and instead tell him plainly who is upsetting him. He wants a straightforward answer rather than more emotional expressions.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo is saying that asking a sick man to make his will is a cruel and poorly timed request. He then clarifies that he is using "sadness" to mean "seriously," and confesses that he is truly in love with a woman.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: Benvolio says he was close to guessing correctly when he thought Romeo was in love. He is responding to Romeo’s admission that he is lovesick, confirming Benvolio’s earlier suspicion.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo is saying that Rosaline is a perfect target for Cupid's arrow, and she is beautiful. He is expressing that he loves her, but she has rejected him.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: Benvolio is telling Romeo that the easiest target to strike is a beautiful one. He means that a woman who is clearly attractive is the simplest to pursue and win over.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo says Rosaline is immune to love because she has vowed to remain chaste like Diana, the goddess of virginity. She cannot be won over by romantic words, flirtatious looks, or expensive gifts. Her beauty is her only wealth, but since she refuses to marry and have children, that beauty will die with her and leave no legacy.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content:
She has vowed to remain a virgin and never marry.  
This means she is rejecting all romantic advances and will not return Romeo's affection.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo complains that Rosaline’s vow of chastity is wasteful because her refusal to have children means her beauty will die with her. He says she is too beautiful and virtuous for her own good, since her decision to reject love causes him misery while she remains untouched.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: Benvolio advises Romeo to stop thinking about Rosaline and move on. He is telling Romeo to follow his advice and let go of his unrequited love.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo is asking for a way to stop his own thoughts, which are consumed by his unrequited love for Rosaline. He feels tormented by his constant brooding and desperately wants to learn how to erase these painful thoughts from his mind.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: Benvolio advises Romeo to free his gaze and look at other beautiful women. He means Romeo should stop fixating on Rosaline and consider other potential romantic interests.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo says that seeing other beautiful women only reminds him of Rosaline's superior beauty, just as a black mask makes one think of the fair skin it conceals. He claims that once you have lost something precious—like his love—you cannot forget it, and any new beauty merely serves as a reminder of what you have lost. Therefore, he insists that no one can make him forget Rosaline.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: Benvolio is saying he will prove the truth of his advice—that Romeo should examine other beauties to forget Rosaline—or consider himself indebted for failing. The phrase "die in debt" means he would owe Romeo a moral debt if his counsel proves wrong.

speaker: CAPULET
content: Capulet is reassuring Paris that the Prince's threat of execution applies equally to both himself and Montague. He believes that as elderly men, they should find it easy to maintain the peace and avoid further conflict.

speaker: PARIS
content: Paris is flattering Capulet by acknowledging his and Montague's respected status, then immediately shifts to his main purpose: asking for a decision about marrying Juliet. "Suit" here means his formal request or proposal for her hand in marriage.

speaker: CAPULET
content: Capulet is telling Paris that Juliet is too young for marriage, as she's not yet fourteen. He suggests waiting two more years before considering her ready to be a bride, emphasizing her youth and inexperience.

speaker: PARIS
content: Paris is arguing that girls even younger than Juliet are already married and have become mothers, implying there is no reason for Capulet to delay the marriage. He uses this point to gently pressure Juliet's father, suggesting that her youth should not be an obstacle to their union.

speaker: CAPULET
content:
Capulet tells Paris that his daughter Juliet is his only surviving child and sole heir. He gives Paris permission to court her but insists Juliet must also agree to the match, showing he respects her choice despite his own approval.

He then invites Paris to a feast at his home that evening, promising he'll see many beautiful young women there. Capulet poetically compares these women to stars brightening the night and to spring flowers replacing winter, suggesting Paris might find someone he likes even more than Juliet.

Finally, Capulet instructs his servant to deliver invitations throughout Verona, extending welcome to all on the list.

speaker: SERVANT
content: The servant is complaining that he's been given a list of names to find, but he can't read it himself. He humorously mixes up tradesmen's tools—saying shoemakers should stick to their yards (measuring sticks) and tailors to their lasts (shoe molds)—to highlight how he's being asked to do something beyond his skills. He's relieved to see Romeo and Benvolio approach, hoping they can read the list for him.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: Benvolio advises Romeo to get over his infatuation with Rosaline by finding a new romantic interest. He uses metaphors of fire and poison to argue that a new emotional "infection" will cure the old one, essentially suggesting that Romeo should distract himself by pursuing another woman.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo is sarcastically dismissing Benvolio's suggestion that another woman could cure his lovesickness. "Plantain leaf" was a common folk remedy for minor cuts and bruises, so Romeo is mockingly implying that Benvolio's advice is as useless as a basic bandage for his deep emotional wound. He means that no simple remedy can fix his profound heartache over Rosaline.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: Benvolio is asking Romeo to explain the reason for his deep sadness. He's gently prompting his cousin to open up about what's troubling him, showing his concern as a friend trying to understand Romeo's melancholy mood.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo is making a sarcastic joke in response to a servant's request for help reading a list. He suggests the servant's "broken shin" is a reason for his inability to read, but this is a flimsy excuse, as a leg injury doesn't affect one's eyesight. This shows Romeo's witty, melancholic mood as he mocks the idea of finding a logical cause for his own lovesick misery.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: Benvolio is concerned and surprised by Romeo's extreme distress, asking if he has lost his sanity. This shows Benvolio's role as a caring, level-headed friend trying to understand Romeo's intense emotional state.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo is describing his lovesick misery as a form of imprisonment and torture, worse than that of a madman. His speech is cut off when he notices the servant approaching and offers a casual greeting, "God-den" (good evening). The servant's immediate question about reading is crucial, as it will lead Romeo to the Capulet's feast and his meeting with Juliet.

speaker: SERVANT
content: The servant greets Romeo politely, saying "God give you good evening." He then asks if Romeo can read because he has been given a list of party guests to invite but is illiterate himself and needs help.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo sarcastically says his misfortune is his only possession. The servant misunderstands, thinking "learned without book" means memorized, and asks if Romeo can read. This exchange allows the servant to unknowingly invite Romeo to the Capulet feast where he'll meet Juliet.

speaker: SERVANT
content: The servant is asking if the person can read anything at all, not just something memorized. He needs help reading a list of party guests because he himself is illiterate. This exchange introduces the crucial plot point that will allow Romeo to learn about the Capulet feast.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo confirms he can read, which is crucial because the illiterate servant has just asked for help reading the guest list for the Capulets' party. This chance encounter directly leads Romeo to the party where he will meet Juliet, setting the entire plot in motion.

speaker: SERVANT
content: The servant politely dismisses the person he was speaking to, wishing them well. He says "rest you merry," which is an archaic way of saying "stay happy" or "good day to you." This signals the end of their conversation and his departure.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo reads the guest list for Capulet's feast, demonstrating his literacy to the servant. He notes Rosaline's name, which is his real interest, and asks where the party is being held. The servant's one-word reply, "Up," means "to the house," directing Romeo to the party location.

speaker: SERVANT
content: The servant is calling out to someone, likely another servant or a group of people, to get up or to rise. This is a simple, direct command to prompt immediate action, probably to begin their duties for the day.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo asks where the servant is going to supper, and the servant replies that he is going to his master's house. This brief exchange is crucial because the servant then reveals he is carrying the guest list for the Capulet feast, which Romeo will read, leading him to decide to attend and meet Juliet.

speaker: SERVANT
content: The servant is telling the guests that they are invited to his master's house. This is part of his duty to deliver the invitations to the party where Romeo and Juliet will first meet.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo asks which family the servant belongs to, seeking to identify the hosts of the party. The servant's vague reply—"my master's"—fails to provide the specific name Romeo needs, creating a moment of dramatic irony since the audience knows this is the Capulet house.

speaker: SERVANT
content: The servant is clarifying that the list of guests he holds belongs to his master, Capulet. This establishes his role as a household servant tasked with delivering invitations. His brief statement underscores his obedience and the social hierarchy at play.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo has just asked the servant who is giving the feast, so his line is a self-deprecating acknowledgment that he spoke out of turn. The servant, unable to read the guest list, casually invites him to the party, using the idiom "crush a cup of wine" to mean "have a drink." His only condition is that Romeo not be a Montague, which is deeply ironic given that Romeo is indeed from the rival house.

speaker: SERVANT
content: The servant is inviting strangers to a party at his master Capulet's house, provided they are not Montagues. He uses the phrase "crush a cup of wine" to mean "have a drink" in a casual, friendly way. This invitation sets up Romeo's chance encounter with Juliet at the feast.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: Benvolio is advising Romeo to attend the Capulet feast to see Rosaline, the woman he loves, alongside other beautiful women of Verona. He urges Romeo to look objectively ("with unattainted eye") and compare Rosaline to others, promising this will make Romeo reconsider his infatuation by showing him someone who outshines her.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo swears that if his eyes, which he treats with religious devotion, ever lie to him by seeing someone more beautiful than Rosaline, they should be punished. He uses the metaphor of his tears turning to fire to burn his own "transparent" (easily seen through) eyes as heretics for such a falsehood. He then declares this impossible, insisting that the sun has never seen anyone to match Rosaline since the world began.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: Benvolio is trying to convince Romeo to move on from Rosaline by challenging his perspective. He argues that Romeo only thinks Rosaline is beautiful because he hasn't compared her to anyone else. Benvolio promises to show him other beautiful women at the feast, claiming that even Rosaline will seem less impressive in comparison.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo has just agreed to attend the Capulet feast, but he clarifies his reason for going. He states he will not be looking at the other women there; instead, his only purpose is to enjoy the sight of his own beloved, Rosaline, and take delight in her beauty.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
content: Lady Capulet is calling for her daughter Juliet to come speak with her. The Nurse responds with a comic oath about her own virginity at age twelve, then affectionately calls for Juliet using pet names like "lamb" and "ladybird."

speaker: NURSE
content: The Nurse swears on her virginity—a humorous and ironic oath for an old nurse—that she called for Juliet when she was twelve. Her exclamations ("lamb," "ladybird") are affectionate nicknames, showing her deep, motherly fondness for Juliet as she impatiently calls her to appear.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet is responding to being summoned, showing her readiness to attend to her mother. The Nurse immediately identifies Lady Capulet as the caller, establishing the domestic setting and Juliet's obedient role within her family.

speaker: NURSE
content: The Nurse is answering Juliet's question about who is calling for her. She clarifies that it is Lady Capulet, Juliet's mother, who wants to speak with her. This simple reply establishes the immediate situation and the person Juliet must now attend to.

speaker: JULIET
content: Julet is responding to her mother's summons with formal obedience. Her question shows she is ready to listen to Lady Capulet's instructions, establishing their relationship as proper but distant. This polite deference sets the stage for the significant request about marriage that follows.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
content: Lady Capulet initially dismisses the Nurse so she can speak privately with Juliet about marriage, but immediately calls her back, acknowledging the Nurse's close relationship with her daughter. The Nurse eagerly confirms her intimate knowledge of Juliet's life, establishing her as a trusted confidante in this discussion. This shows Lady Capulet's indecisiveness about the Nurse's role and highlights the Nurse's deep involvement in Juliet's upbringing.

speaker: NURSE
content: The Nurse boasts to Lady Capulet that she knows Juliet's exact age down to the hour. This emphasizes her long, intimate history with the family and her role as a mother figure, establishing her as a key source of information about Juliet.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
content: Lady Capulet is correcting the Nurse, emphasizing that Juliet is not yet fourteen years old. The Nurse humorously agrees, swearing by her few remaining teeth, and asks how long it is until Lammas-tide (August 1st), which is Juliet’s birthday. This exchange highlights Juliet’s youth and the Nurse’s fond, familiar manner.

speaker: NURSE
content: The Nurse is humorously emphasizing that Juliet is not yet fourteen by offering a ridiculous wager—she'd bet fourteen teeth, even though she only has four left. She then asks Lady Capulet to confirm the exact time until Lammas-tide (August 1st), which is Juliet's birthday, showing her affectionate, familiar role in the household.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
content: The Nurse is correcting Lady Capulet's estimate of Juliet's age, insisting she will be fourteen on Lammas Eve (August 1st). She then launches into a rambling, sentimental memory of weaning Juliet, using bitter wormwood on her breast, and recalls her late husband's joking prophecy that Juliet would "fall backward" (a sexual innuendo about lying down for a man) when she grew wiser. This long-winded, earthy speech characterizes the Nurse as a garrulous, lower-class figure who views love in physical terms, contrasting sharply with Lady Capulet's more formal and distant relationship with her daughter.

speaker: NURSE
content: The Nurse is telling Lady Capulet that Juliet will turn fourteen on Lammas Eve (July 31st), but she gets sidetracked into a long, rambling story about Juliet as a baby. She recalls weaning Juliet with bitter wormwood, an earthquake that happened at the same time, and her late husband's crude joke that Juliet would one day "fall backward"—a sexual innuendo meaning she would lie down for a man. This digression reveals the Nurse's earthy, affectionate nature and her long, intimate history with the family.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
content: Lady Capulet is impatiently telling the Nurse to stop talking. The Nurse, however, ignores this and continues reminiscing about a humorous memory from Juliet's childhood. She recalls a time when the toddler Juliet fell and had a bump on her head, and her husband joked that Juliet would "fall backward" (a euphemism for having sex) when she was older, to which the young Juliet innocently agreed.

speaker: NURSE
content: The Nurse is recalling a humorous memory of Juliet as a toddler, who stopped crying and said "Yes" after a bad fall. Her husband joked that if Juliet fell forward now, she'd fall backward (a sexual innuendo about lying down for a man) when she grew older—and young Juliet innocently agreed again. This shows the Nurse's earthy, familiar relationship with Juliet and foreshadows Juliet's future romantic experiences.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet is impatiently telling her Nurse to stop talking. The Nurse responds by blessing Juliet, recalling her as the most beautiful baby she ever cared for, and expressing her wish to see Juliet married someday.

speaker: NURSE
content: The Nurse is telling Juliet to be quiet because she's finished speaking. She affectionately recalls that Juliet was the most beautiful baby she ever cared for and says her only wish is to live long enough to see Juliet get married.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
content: "Marry" here is an archaic interjection meaning "indeed" or "by the Virgin Mary." Lady Capulet is telling Juliet that marriage is exactly the subject she came to discuss. She then directly asks her daughter how she feels about the prospect of getting married.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet is politely deflecting her mother's suggestion of marriage, saying she hasn't even considered it yet. The Nurse, in her earthy way, finds this response so unexpectedly wise that she jokes Juliet must have gained wisdom directly from breastfeeding.

speaker: NURSE
content: The Nurse is telling Juliet that it's an honor to be her only nurse, and she playfully suggests that if she weren't, she would say Juliet got her wisdom from breastfeeding. This affectionate exaggeration highlights the Nurse's deep bond with Juliet and her pride in having raised her.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
content:
Lady Capulet is urging Juliet to consider marrying Paris, pointing out that many respected young women in Verona are already mothers at her age. She emphasizes her own early motherhood to strengthen her argument.

The Nurse enthusiastically agrees, calling Paris a perfect man—"a man of wax" means he's as handsome as a statue. She is reinforcing Lady Capulet's matchmaking efforts with her characteristic earthy praise.

speaker: NURSE
content: The Nurse is enthusiastically praising Paris to Juliet, calling him a perfect specimen of a man, as if he were a flawless wax statue. She means he is handsome, ideal, and admired by everyone.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
content: Lady Capulet is telling Juliet that Paris is the finest young man in Verona, comparing his qualities to the most beautiful summer flower. The Nurse enthusiastically agrees, reinforcing the compliment to emphasize that Paris is an exceptionally handsome and worthy suitor.

speaker: NURSE
content: The Nurse is praising Paris, calling him a perfect example of a fine young man, comparing him to a beautiful flower. She is enthusiastically agreeing with Lady Capulet, who has just been describing Paris as a worthy suitor for Juliet.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
content: Lady Capulet is urging Juliet to consider marrying Paris, using an extended metaphor comparing him to a beautiful book. She tells Juliet to study Paris's face and features at the feast that night, suggesting his inner qualities are visible in his eyes. The metaphor continues as she claims Paris, like an unbound book, only needs a wife—the "cover"—to be complete, implying that marriage to him will elevate Juliet's status.

speaker: NURSE
content: The Nurse crudely jokes that women grow physically larger during pregnancy. She is telling Lady Capulet that Juliet is mature enough for marriage and motherhood.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
content: Lady Capulet is asking Juliet if she could develop romantic feelings for Paris. She wants a quick, direct answer because she is eager to arrange a marriage. This question pressures Juliet to consider a suitor she has not yet met.

speaker: JULIET
content: Julet tells her mother she will consider Paris as a potential suitor, but promises not to let her feelings develop any further than her mother's permission allows. The phrase "looking liking move" means she'll try to like him if simply seeing him can inspire affection. She uses the metaphor of a dart to represent her gaze, vowing not to let it fly deeper than her mother approves.

speaker: SERVANT
content: The servant breathlessly reports that the Capulet feast is in full chaotic swing: guests have arrived, dinner is ready, Juliet is being summoned, and the Nurse is being scolded in the pantry. He urgently asks Lady Capulet to follow him immediately because he must return to his duties.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
content: Lady Capulet is telling the Nurse to lead the way, showing she defers to the Nurse's familiarity with Juliet's daily life. This brief line establishes the Nurse's intimate, guiding role within the household as they go to speak with Juliet about marriage.

speaker: NURSE
content: The Nurse is encouraging Juliet to go enjoy herself at the Capulet feast, hoping she will find romantic happiness there. Her blessing suggests she is more concerned with Juliet's immediate pleasure and potential marriage than with the formalities of courtship.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo is asking his friends whether they should announce their arrival at the party with a formal, prepared speech, or if they should just enter without any introduction. He is weighing the social etiquette of crashing the Capulet feast, revealing his hesitation and reluctance to attend.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: Benvolio dismisses the outdated, overly elaborate custom of masked ball attendees performing a rehearsed, theatrical entrance. He insists their group will skip such a showy preamble and instead go straight to dancing. His plan is to let others judge them as they wish, while they simply dance a measure and then leave.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo asks for a torch because he feels too sad and serious to join in the lighthearted dancing and revelry. He is making a pun on the word "heavy," meaning both emotionally weighed down and physically solid, contrasting his mood with the "light" of the torch and the party atmosphere.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: Mercutio is urging his friend Romeo to join the dancing and shake off his melancholy mood. He playfully insists that Romeo stop being a wallflower and participate in the festivities.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo uses a pun on "soles" (shoes) and "soul" (spirit) to contrast his friends' lighthearted mood with his own heavy heart. He feels weighed down by sadness and love, making him unable to join in the dancing or festivities.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: Mercutio is teasing Romeo for being a lovesick romantic, suggesting he should use the power of love to rise above ordinary limits. "Borrow Cupid’s wings" means to take on the god of love’s ability to fly, and "soar... above a common bound" is a challenge to exceed normal social or emotional constraints.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo is telling his friends he's too emotionally wounded by love to join their lighthearted mood. He feels weighed down by sadness, unable to rise above his misery. The "shaft" refers to Cupid's arrow, which has painfully pierced him instead of inspiring joyful flight.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: Mercutio warns Romeo that taking love too seriously will only weigh it down and crush it. He personifies love as a delicate, fragile thing that cannot withstand such heavy pressure. This continues his earlier mockery of Romeo's intense, romantic melancholy.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo questions whether love is gentle, then immediately contradicts that idea by describing it as harsh and painful. He uses sharp, physical imagery—"rough," "rude," "boisterous"—and compares the sensation to being pricked by a thorn, emphasizing love's capacity to cause hurt rather than comfort.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: Mercutio is advising Romeo to fight back against the pain of love rather than be defeated by it. He then shifts to putting on his mask, joking that his own face is so ugly it's like a mask already. He declares he doesn't care if people stare at his "deformities," as the mask's bushy eyebrows will hide any embarrassment for him.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: Benvolio is urging his friends to enter the Capulet feast and immediately start dancing. The phrase "betake him to his legs" is an old-fashioned way of saying "take to his legs," meaning to get up and dance. He is encouraging them to join the revelry without delay.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo asks for a torch, saying he will hold the light while others, who are carefree and playful, dance. He is quoting an old saying to explain that he will just watch from the sidelines, because he feels the "game"—the party and its possibilities—is no longer appealing to him in his current lovesick state.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: Mercutio is teasing Romeo for being gloomy and stuck in his lovesick thoughts. "Dun's the mouse" is a pun meaning "keep still," but he twists it to imply Romeo is stuck in the mud of love. He urges everyone to stop wasting time and get moving.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo is correcting Mercutio's earlier claim that dreams are meaningless. He insists that dreams can hold truth and significance, setting up his own sense of foreboding about the party. This shows his more serious, fatalistic nature in contrast to Mercutio's playful cynicism.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: Mercutio is telling Romeo they are wasting their torches and time by hesitating to enter the party. He urges Romeo to accept his intended meaning, arguing that their common sense is far more reliable than their individual wits.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo is telling his friends that although their intentions in attending the Capulet party are good, it is still unwise to go. He is expressing his own sense of foreboding, as he feels this night will somehow set in motion a chain of tragic events that will end with his own death.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: Mercutio is responding to Romeo's reluctance to join the dance, challenging his friend's melancholy mood. His question is a direct, slightly impatient prompt for Romeo to explain his mysterious sorrow, setting up Romeo's ensuing confession about his ominous dream.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo is telling his friends that he had a dream last night. He is feeling a sense of foreboding, as he believes this dream hints at some tragic future event that will begin at the party they are about to attend.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: Mercutio is responding to Romeo's claim that he had a dream. He quickly agrees, saying he also dreamed, but then immediately launches into his famous Queen Mab speech to mock the very idea of dreams having any meaning. His purpose is to dismiss Romeo's foreboding as mere fantasy and to cheer up his melancholy friend with a display of wit.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo is asking Mercutio to explain the dream he just mentioned. This question shifts the focus from Romeo's own ominous feelings to Mercutio's more fanciful imagination, setting up Mercutio's famous "Queen Mab" speech.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: Mercutio is responding to Romeo's claim that he had a dream foretelling bad luck from the party. Here, "lie" means both to tell falsehoods and to recline in bed. He dismisses dreams as meaningless fantasies, not prophecies.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo is describing how dreams can feel vividly real while one is asleep. He contrasts this with the deceptive nature of reality, suggesting that dreams can sometimes reveal truths that waking life obscures. This reflects his own troubled state of mind and foreshadows the tragic events that will unfold.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: Mercutio is teasing Romeo for being lovesick by inventing a whimsical story about Queen Mab, the tiny fairy who brings dreams to sleepers. He describes her elaborate miniature carriage and explains how she inspires specific dreams in different people—lovers dream of love, lawyers of fees, soldiers of battle—to show that dreams are just meaningless fantasies. This speech reveals Mercutio’s cynical, witty nature and his belief that Romeo’s romantic notions are foolish and insubstantial.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo is trying to calm his friend Mercutio, who has been delivering a long, fanciful speech about Queen Mab. He tells Mercutio to be quiet, dismissing his wild talk as meaningless. This shows Romeo's more serious and melancholy mood, contrasting with Mercutio's playful energy.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: Mercutio dismisses dreams as meaningless fantasies created by a lazy mind, comparing them to air in their lack of substance. He further emphasizes their unreliability by likening them to the wind, which unpredictably shifts direction—currently blowing north but capable of suddenly turning south. This critique targets Romeo's superstitious fears about the party, urging him toward bold action instead of passive hesitation.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: Benvolio is telling Romeo that their friends' urging to go to the party is distracting them from their original purpose. He then shifts to a practical concern, worrying that they will miss the festivities if they don't hurry.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo expresses a premonition that tonight's festivities will set in motion a chain of events leading to his own untimely death. He feels his life is fated to be cut short by some terrible consequence. However, he resigns himself to fate, asking whoever guides his life to direct his actions, and then urges his friends to proceed.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: Benvolio is giving a command to the drummer to begin playing, signaling their arrival at the Capulet feast. This brief line serves to transition the scene, moving the group of Montague boys from the street into the party.

speaker: FIRST SERVANT
content: The servant is complaining that Potpan is not helping to clear the tables. He sarcastically lists the simple tasks Potpan should be doing, like moving and scraping plates, to emphasize his laziness.

speaker: SECOND SERVANT
content: The servant complains that only one or two people are doing all the work, and even they are dirty and unwashed. He's grumbling about the poor organization and uncleanliness at the feast, suggesting the event is poorly managed.

speaker: FIRST SERVANT
content: The servant is frantically directing other staff to clear away stools and sideboards, secure the silverware, and save him some marzipan. He urgently requests that the doorman admit two women named Susan Grindstone and Nell, calling out for his coworkers Antony and Potpan to help. This chaotic speech vividly illustrates the hectic backstage preparations for the Capulets' grand feast.

speaker: SECOND SERVANT
content: The servant confirms he is prepared for his duties. This brief exchange highlights the bustling, chaotic atmosphere of the Capulet feast as the staff hurriedly makes final preparations.

speaker: FIRST SERVANT
content: The servant urgently tells another staff member that they are being summoned by multiple people in the main hall. The repetitive phrasing emphasizes the immediacy and importance of the request, highlighting the chaotic, demanding atmosphere of the Capulet feast.

speaker: SECOND SERVANT
content: The servant complains that they cannot be in two places at once, urging his fellow workers to be cheerful and quick in their duties. His phrase "the longer liver take all" means whoever lives longest gets everything, a cynical comment on life's uncertainty. This brief moment highlights the chaotic backstage reality of the lavish Capulet feast.

speaker: CAPULET
content: Capulet is warmly welcoming his guests and encouraging them to dance, teasing the ladies that anyone who hesitates must have sore feet from corns. He nostalgically recalls his own youth when he was a charming masker at parties, but acknowledges that time has passed. He then shifts to practical host duties, calling for more light, cooler air, and music, while also gently insisting his older relative sit down with him since they are both beyond such youthful revelry.

speaker: CAPULET'S COUSIN
content: "By’r Lady" is a mild oath meaning "By Our Lady" (the Virgin Mary). Capulet's cousin is confirming that it has been thirty years since he last wore a mask to a party like this one, emphasizing how long it has been since he last celebrated in such a fashion.

speaker: CAPULET
content: Capulet is telling his cousin that it has been about twenty-five years since they last wore masks at a party, which was at Lucentio's wedding. He's reminiscing about the past to emphasize how long it's been since they've celebrated in this way, adding to the festive and nostalgic mood of the scene.

speaker: CAPULET'S COUSIN
content: Capulet's cousin is correcting someone who underestimated the age of a guest's son. He clarifies that the son is actually older than previously thought—specifically thirty years old. This brief exchange shows the older generation's focus on social details and family status during the party.

speaker: CAPULET
content: Capulet is dismissing a guest's concern about Romeo's youth, arguing that he is too young to pose any threat. He emphasizes that Romeo was still a minor under legal guardianship just two years prior, implying the boy is still immature and harmless.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo is asking a servant to identify a beautiful woman he has just seen, showing his immediate captivation. The servant's ignorance heightens the mystery and Romeo's urgency to find out who she is.

speaker: SERVANT
content: The servant admits he doesn't know the identity of the masked guest. This highlights the chaotic atmosphere of the Capulet feast where uninvited guests like Romeo can slip in unnoticed. His ignorance directly enables the fateful meeting between Romeo and Juliet.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo is stunned by Juliet's beauty, which he says outshines everyone else like a jewel against dark skin or a dove among crows. He resolves to approach her after the dance, hoping that touching her hand will bless his own. He instantly renounces any past affection, declaring he has never seen true beauty until this moment.

speaker: TYBALT
content: Tybalt recognizes Romeo's voice as belonging to a Montague and immediately calls for his sword. He is outraged that Romeo would dare to attend their feast, believing he has come in disguise to mock their celebration. Tybalt swears on his family's honor that he would feel no guilt in killing Romeo for this offense.

speaker: CAPULET
content: Capulet is addressing Tybalt, who is furious at seeing Romeo at the party. He is asking Tybalt why he is so angry and causing a disturbance.

speaker: TYBALT
content: Tybalt alerts his uncle, Lord Capulet, that Romeo—a member of their rival family—has come to their feast uninvited. He claims Romeo is there out of malice to mock and disrupt their celebration. This accusation reveals Tybalt's hot-headed nature and escalates the tension, setting up their later confrontation.

speaker: CAPULET
content: Capulet recognizes Romeo, a Montague, at his party. He restrains Tybalt from confronting him, showing his authority and desire to avoid a public scene that would disrupt his feast.

speaker: TYBALT
content: Tybalt recognizes Romeo, a Montague, at the Capulet feast and immediately identifies him as an enemy. He calls Romeo a "villain" to express his outrage that an adversary has dared to intrude upon his family's party, setting the stage for his vengeful anger.

speaker: CAPULET
content: Capulet is telling Tybalt to calm down and leave Romeo alone, since Romeo is behaving respectfully and has a good reputation in Verona. He insists that, as host, he will not allow any guest to be insulted in his home, and he orders Tybalt to stop frowning and be pleasant for the sake of the party.

speaker: TYBALT
content: Tybalt is furious that Romeo, a Montague, has dared to attend the Capulet feast. He declares that he will not tolerate Romeo's presence, seeing him as a villain who has invaded his family's party.

speaker: CAPULET
content: Capulet is angrily rebuking Tybalt for challenging Romeo's presence at the feast. He asserts his authority as the host, warning Tybalt that his hot-headedness will cause a riot among the guests. The phrase "set cock-a-hoop" means to behave recklessly and cause disorder.

speaker: TYBALT
content: Tybalt is complaining to his uncle, Lord Capulet, that Romeo, a Montague, has dared to attend their family's party. He feels this is a disgrace and an insult to their household's honor.

speaker: CAPULET
content: Capulet is scolding Tybalt for being a hot-headed, insolent youth after Tybalt wants to fight Romeo at the party. He warns Tybalt that his defiant attitude will get him into trouble, calling him a "princox" (an impertinent youngster). Abruptly switching from anger to public cheer, Capulet tells the guests to enjoy themselves, showing he wants to avoid a scene and maintain the festive mood.

speaker: TYBALT
content: Tybalt is restraining his fury at seeing Romeo, a Montague, at the Capulet feast. He says this forced patience clashing with his anger makes him physically tremble. Although he will leave for now, he vows that Romeo's intrusion, which seems harmless now, will later turn into a cause for bitter hatred and revenge.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo addresses Juliet as a sacred figure, comparing his hand's touch to a "profane" act against a "holy shrine." He suggests his lips, like devout "pilgrims," can atone for this by giving a kiss, using religious metaphor to elevate their encounter and seek permission for intimacy.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet is playfully correcting Romeo's overly humble gesture of touching her hand. She uses religious imagery—comparing herself to a saint and Romeo to a pilgrim—to suggest that their hand-touching is not a wrongdoing but a holy, acceptable form of greeting. This cleverly reframes their physical contact as an act of devotion rather than impropriety.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo is asking Juliet if saints and pilgrims don't also have lips, using religious imagery to justify a kiss. This continues his metaphor of himself as a pilgrim and her as a holy shrine, cleverly turning her earlier, more cautious words into a playful argument for them to kiss.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet is playfully responding to Romeo's metaphor of himself as a pilgrim and her as a holy shrine. She suggests that, like a pilgrim, he should use his lips for prayer rather than for a kiss. This clever, pious excuse is actually a flirtatious invitation for him to justify why he should kiss her instead.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo uses a religious metaphor to ask Juliet for a kiss. He suggests that if their hands have touched in prayer, their lips should also meet, or else his devout faith in her will become hopeless despair. This cleverly frames his desire as a holy request, blending romance with spiritual imagery to persuade her.

speaker: JULIET
content: Julet is telling Romeo not to touch her, as saints are statues that don't move, even when they grant prayers. She uses this holy metaphor to playfully suggest that if he wants to kiss her, he should do it himself without her moving to initiate it.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo asks Juliet to stay still so he can kiss her, playfully framing it as a religious act where his "sin" of touching her is purified by her lips. This metaphor elevates their first meeting into something sacred, showing his immediate, intense devotion.

speaker: JULIET
content: Julet playfully suggests that if it was a sin for Romeo to kiss her, she now shares that sin by kissing him back. This witty reply shows her immediate willingness to participate in their flirtation, matching Romeo's boldness with clever religious wordplay.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo is responding to Juliet's playful accusation that their first kiss was a "sin." He cleverly turns this around, saying that if it's a sin, it's a delightful one, and he asks her to kiss him again so he can have his "sin" back. This exchange uses religious language to flirt and shows their immediate, witty connection.

speaker: JULIET
content: Julet is playfully teasing Romeo after their first kiss, suggesting he kisses perfectly—as if following a manual on the subject. This shows her wit and immediate comfort with him. The Nurse then interrupts to summon Juliet to her mother, abruptly ending their intimate moment.

speaker: NURSE
content: The Nurse is informing Juliet that her mother, Lady Capulet, wishes to speak with her. This interruption serves to separate Juliet from Romeo, ending their first conversation and creating a moment of suspense.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo is asking the Nurse who Juliet's mother is, hoping to learn more about her family. The Nurse explains that Juliet's mother is Lady Capulet, the hostess of the ball, and adds that she is respectable and honorable. She also reveals that she herself was Juliet's wet-nurse and hints that whoever marries Juliet will be wealthy—"have the chinks," meaning plenty of money.

speaker: NURSE
content: The Nurse tells Romeo that Juliet is the daughter of the wealthy Capulet household, emphasizing her mother's high status and virtue. She then reveals she was Juliet's wet-nurse and hints that whoever marries Juliet will be rich, using the slang "chinks" to mean money.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo has just learned that Juliet is a Capulet, his family's sworn enemy. He exclaims that his life is now in the hands of his foe, meaning his love for Juliet makes him completely vulnerable to his enemy's family.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: Benvolio is urging the group to leave the party because the festivities have reached their peak and will only decline from there. He is concerned that if they stay longer, they risk being discovered by the Capulets, which could lead to trouble.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo is confirming that his fears are justified, which only increases his inner turmoil. He is responding to a warning about the dangers of attending the Capulet feast, and this line reveals his growing anxiety and sense of foreboding.

speaker: CAPULET
content: Capulet is urging his guests not to leave yet, insisting they stay for a light, informal meal. He then quickly changes his mind, thanking them and saying goodnight because he realizes it is actually very late. His sudden shift shows he is an affable but perhaps slightly disorganized host, and his call for more torches and declaration that he is going to bed signals the party is officially over.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet is asking her Nurse to identify a man she sees across the room. The Nurse replies that he is the son and heir of old Tiberio, referring to Tybalt. This brief exchange shows Juliet's immediate interest in Romeo, whom she has just met, and the Nurse's role as her source of information.

speaker: NURSE
content: The Nurse is identifying a young man as the son and heir of Old Tiberio. This is her slightly mistaken way of referring to Tybalt, Juliet's cousin, as she is not great with names. She is pointing him out to Juliet, likely in response to a question about who he is.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet is asking her Nurse to identify the man leaving the party, showing her immediate interest in Romeo after their first meeting. The Nurse misunderstands and identifies the wrong person, "young Petruchio," delaying Juliet's discovery of Romeo's identity and name.

speaker: NURSE
content: "Marry" here is a mild oath, like "indeed." The Nurse is identifying a guest at the Capulet party, noting that she believes the man she sees is a young man named Petruchio. This serves to ground the scene in a specific, known character for the audience.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet is asking her Nurse to identify Romeo, who has just caught her attention. She notes that he didn't join the dancing, making him stand out. The Nurse admits she doesn't recognize him, prompting Juliet's next line where she learns his identity as a Montague.

speaker: NURSE
content: The Nurse is pretending ignorance here, likely to protect Juliet. Her brief, evasive answer creates tension and forces Romeo to identify himself, allowing her to then report back to Juliet with the crucial information about who he is.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet urgently asks her nurse to identify the stranger, revealing that if he is already married, she feels she will die unmarried. This shows her immediate, intense devotion to Romeo. The nurse's reply—that he is Romeo Montague, their enemy's son—creates the central conflict: Juliet's love is forbidden.

speaker: NURSE
content: The Nurse is telling Juliet that the man she just kissed is Romeo Montague, the son of the family her own family despises. This revelation creates immediate conflict, as Juliet now knows her new love interest is from the rival house.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet realizes with horror that the man she just fell in love with is Romeo, a Montague—the son of her family's sworn enemy. She laments that she saw him before learning his identity, and now her love feels like a monstrous omen because it is for a "loathed enemy." The Nurse's abrupt questions show she has overheard and is demanding an explanation.

speaker: NURSE
content: The Nurse is reacting with surprise and alarm to Juliet's sudden interest in Romeo, whom she has just learned is a Montague. Her repeated exclamation shows her shock at this dangerous turn of events, as she immediately understands the implications of Juliet falling for their family's enemy.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet is telling her Nurse that she just learned a rhyme from the person she danced with—Romeo. The Nurse urgently calls her away because the party is over and all the guests have left.

speaker: NURSE
content: The Nurse is urgently calling Juliet to leave the party, telling her that all the guests ("strangers") have departed. This abrupt exit creates a sense of urgency and marks the end of the public celebration, immediately shifting the scene to the private world of Romeo and Juliet's newfound love.

speaker: CHORUS
content: The Chorus explains that Romeo has completely forgotten his infatuation with Rosaline and is now entirely captivated by Juliet. However, their new love is immediately complicated because their families are enemies, making it dangerous for them to meet or speak openly. Despite these severe obstacles, their intense passion will give them the courage and ingenuity to find a way to be together, transforming their extreme danger into something profoundly sweet.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo is torn between leaving and staying near Juliet, whom he calls his "heart." He addresses his body as "dull earth," commanding it to return to Juliet, who is its "centre" or gravitational core. This metaphor emphasizes his belief that his true place is with her, leading him to climb into the Capulet orchard.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: Benvolio is calling out for Romeo, who has just slipped away from his friends after the Capulet feast. He is concerned about Romeo's whereabouts and well-being, trying to locate him in the dark. This highlights Romeo's sudden isolation as he is now solely focused on his new love for Juliet.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: Mercutio is sarcastically suggesting that Romeo, having disappeared after the party, has wisely gone home to bed. He is mocking Romeo's lovesick behavior and trying to provoke him to come out of hiding by calling him "wise" for avoiding their company.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: Benvolio is telling Mercutio that Romeo has escaped them by climbing over the wall of a private garden. He suggests Mercutio call out for him, hoping to lure Romeo back without having to follow him into the private property.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: Mercutio is mocking Romeo's lovesick behavior by sarcastically calling on him as if he were a spirit to be summoned. He lists exaggerated romantic clichés—like sighing, rhyming "love" with "dove," and invoking Venus and Cupid—to tease Romeo for his melodramatic passion. The crude reference to Rosaline's body ("demesnes that there adjacent lie") underscores Mercutio's view that Romeo's infatuation is more about physical desire than true love.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: Benvolio warns Mercutio that Romeo is nearby and will be upset by his mocking words. He cautions that Romeo, likely hiding in the darkness, will take offense to the jokes being made at his expense.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: Mercutio is explaining to Benvolio that his teasing won't actually anger Romeo. He jokes that it would only be truly offensive if he were conjuring a sexual spirit in Rosaline's "circle" (a crude pun on female anatomy) and making it remain there. Instead, Mercutio claims his calls are "fair and honest" because he's only trying to "raise up" Romeo himself, not anything inappropriate.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: Benvolio suggests Romeo has hidden among the trees to keep company with the moody, damp night. He means Romeo's infatuation is irrational—"blind"—and therefore suited to darkness, where reason doesn't apply.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: Mercutio mocks Romeo's lovesick state with crude sexual puns, suggesting he wishes Rosaline were a "medlar" (a fruit slang for female genitalia) and Romeo a "poperin pear" (slang for penis). He then gives up on summoning Romeo, declaring the outdoor "field-bed" too cold and heading indoors to his "truckle-bed" (a small bed on wheels).

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: Benvolio is telling Mercutio to give up searching for Romeo, who has climbed over the orchard wall. He means that it's pointless to look for someone who is deliberately hiding and doesn't want to be found.

speaker: ROMEO
content:
Romeo, having just overheard Mercutio's crude jokes about love, dismisses them as the words of someone who has never been in love himself. He then sees Juliet on her balcony and immediately launches into a series of rapturous comparisons, establishing the play's central light/dark imagery.

He first metaphorically transforms her into the sun, commanding this "fair sun" to replace the "envious moon," which represents the pale, virginal Diana. He urges Juliet to reject this "vestal livery" (the chaste, green-sick appearance of the moon) and not to remain a virgin.

His adoration then focuses on her silent presence, believing her eyes speak volumes he feels he can answer. He imagines her eyes are so bright that two stars have borrowed them, and that their light in the sky would be so brilliant it would fool birds into singing as if it were day. The speech culminates in his intimate, yearning wish to be a glove on her hand so he could touch her cheek.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet sighs in frustration, expressing her sudden realization that she has fallen in love with Romeo—a Montague, her family's sworn enemy. This brief exclamation reveals her inner conflict and sets the tone for her following soliloquy about the complications of their newfound love.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo hears Juliet speak and is overwhelmed by her voice, comparing her to a divine angel whose presence is as awe-inspiring to him as an archangel appearing in the sky is to mortals on earth. He uses exalted imagery—"white-upturned wondering eyes" and "bestrides the lazy-puffing clouds"—to convey how her words elevate her above ordinary experience, making her seem heavenly and unattainable. This expresses his instant, worshipful infatuation and the sense of wonder she inspires in him.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet is lamenting that Romeo is a Montague, her family's enemy. "Wherefore" means "why"—she's asking why he must be Romeo Montague. She declares that if he renounces his name or pledges his love to her, she will abandon her own family name to be with him.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo is debating whether to continue eavesdropping on Juliet or to reveal his presence. He is torn between listening to her private thoughts and interrupting to declare his own love. This aside reveals his internal conflict and heightens the tension of the moment.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet argues that Romeo's name is meaningless—it's an artificial label, not part of his true self. She uses the famous rose analogy to claim that his inner worth would remain unchanged even if he had a different name. She then urges him symbolically to abandon his family name, offering herself in exchange.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo eagerly accepts Juliet's offer to deny his family name. He declares that if she calls him her "love," he will be reborn with a new identity, abandoning the name "Romeo" and the feud it represents forever.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet is startled by an unseen man in the dark who has overheard her private thoughts. She demands to know his identity, using "bescreen'd" to mean hidden and "counsel" to refer to her secret musings about Romeo. This establishes the tension and secrecy of their nighttime meeting.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo is telling Juliet that he hates his own name because it is Montague, the family she is sworn to hate. He is so desperate to erase this barrier between them that he claims he would physically destroy the word if it were written down.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet recognizes Romeo's voice after hearing only a few words, showing how instantly familiar he has become to her. She confirms his identity by asking if he is both Romeo and a Montague, acknowledging the dangerous family rivalry that complicates their connection.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo is assuring Juliet that he is neither a Montague nor a Capulet if she finds either name offensive. He means that he would willingly give up his family name and identity for her love. This shows his immediate and total devotion, prioritizing his feelings for her over his family allegiance.

speaker: JULIET
content: Julet is startled to find Romeo in her family's orchard and immediately asks how and why he came. She points out the physical danger of the high walls and the mortal danger he is in, as her kinsmen would kill him if they discovered a Montague on their property. Her tone is a mixture of wonder and urgent concern for his safety.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo explains that he climbed the high walls to reach Juliet by imagining love gave him wings, since physical barriers cannot block love. He insists that her relatives are no obstacle because love will dare to try anything it is capable of.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet warns Romeo that if her family's guards spot him, they will kill him. She expresses immediate fear for his safety, emphasizing the real danger he faces by trespassing on Capulet property. This shows her protective concern overriding her own family loyalty.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo tells Juliet that her angry or disapproving look is more dangerous to him than the swords of twenty of her family members. He is saying that if she will only look at him with kindness, he will feel protected and invulnerable to the hatred of his enemies.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet is expressing her fear that Romeo will be discovered by her family's guards if he remains in the orchard. She means she would not want him to be seen there under any circumstances, as it would put him in grave danger. This shows her immediate concern for his safety over her own feelings.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo tells Juliet that darkness conceals him from her family. He declares he would rather be killed by the Capulets now than live a long life without her love, emphasizing that her love is more important to him than his own life.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet is asking Romeo how he managed to find her balcony, expressing her surprise and concern for his safety. She worries that if her kinsmen were to discover him, he would be in grave danger.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo explains that love guided him to find Juliet and gave him the wisdom to seek her out. He then uses a metaphor of a merchant sailing to a distant shore to declare that, even if she were impossibly far away, he would still risk the journey to reach her.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet acknowledges that the darkness hides her blushes, or she’d be embarrassed Romeo overheard her private declaration of love. She admits she’s bypassing customary coyness to ask directly if he loves her, but immediately worries that if he swears it, he might be lying—since, as the saying goes, the gods laugh at lovers’ broken vows. She then frets that her openness might make her seem too easily won, but insists her love is more genuine than that of women who play hard to get, and she asks him not to mistake her honesty for shallowness.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo swears his love by the moon, which he describes as "blessed" and silvering the orchard trees. He uses this grand, romantic oath to convince Juliet of his sincerity and devotion.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet asks Romeo not to swear his love by the moon because it is "inconstant," meaning it changes its appearance every month as it orbits the Earth. She fears that if he swears by something so changeable, his love for her might also prove fickle and unreliable.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo is asking what he should swear an oath on to prove his love is sincere. He is responding to Juliet's concern that their vows are happening too quickly and might be insincere. This shows his eagerness to convince her and his willingness to pledge by anything she chooses.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet is telling Romeo not to swear his love by the moon, which is changeable, because she wants a vow that is as constant as his own self. By asking him to swear "by thy gracious self," she elevates him to a god-like status in her personal worship, showing the depth of her devotion. This reveals her desire for a sincere and unwavering commitment from him.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo is declaring that his love for Juliet is so profound that he is willing to give up his family name, the very thing that defines him, to be with her. He is speaking to Juliet, trying to convince her that the feud between their families is a trivial obstacle compared to his devotion.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet urges Romeo not to swear his love by the moon because it is inconstant, changing its position in the sky every night. She fears that if he swears by something so variable, his love might prove equally changeable and unreliable.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo is asking Juliet if she will end their secret meeting without giving him what he truly desires—a formal commitment or vow of love. The word "unsatisfied" here refers to his emotional longing, not a physical need. He fears their intense exchange will end without the reassurance of her affection and a promise for their future.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet is asking Romeo what assurance or fulfillment he can possibly offer her this evening. She is questioning the sincerity and feasibility of his romantic advances, given their families' feud and the suddenness of their love. This shows her practical concern and desire for a serious commitment rather than fleeting words.

speaker: ROMEO
