speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: The Friar informs Romeo that he has been exiled from Verona as punishment for killing Tybalt. He urges Romeo to be patient and see his situation in a larger context, reminding him that there are other places to live besides Verona.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo argues that being banished from Verona is worse than death, since outside the city walls lies only suffering. He accuses Friar Laurence of using the gentle word "banished" to disguise a death sentence, comparing it to being executed with a luxurious but still fatal axe.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: The Friar scolds Romeo for his ingratitude, pointing out that the Prince has shown him mercy by commuting his death sentence to banishment. He emphasizes that Romeo is failing to recognize this act of leniency as the fortunate reprieve it truly is.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo is lamenting to Friar Laurence that banishment from Verona is a fate worse than death because it separates him from Juliet. He envies even the lowliest creatures in the city, who can still see her, while he is forbidden. He accuses the Friar of cruelty for offering exile as a solution, equating the word "banished" with the torments of hell.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: The Friar is scolding Romeo for his rash despair after killing Tybalt and being banished. He calls Romeo "fond" (foolish) and "mad" to emphasize how irrational he is being, and he demands that Romeo stop lamenting and listen to his practical advice.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo is anticipating that Friar Laurence will repeat the word "banishment," a punishment he finds worse than death. He dreads hearing it because it means permanent separation from Juliet. This shows his despair and how he equates exile with a living death.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: The Friar is telling Romeo that he will provide him with a defense against his sorrow. He calls philosophy "adversity's sweet milk," meaning it is a nourishing source of comfort. He offers this wisdom to console Romeo in his state of banishment.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo dismisses any attempt to find comfort in reason or logic. He argues that philosophy is useless because it cannot bring Juliet to him or undo the Prince's decree of banishment. This outburst reveals his despair and his refusal to be consoled, as he sees his separation from Juliet as a fate worse than death.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: The Friar is frustrated that Romeo isn't listening to his logical advice. He means that people who are acting irrationally ("mad men") are incapable of hearing reason. This is his exasperated reaction to Romeo's hysterical despair over his banishment.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo is arguing that even wise men lack foresight, so how could the stars—which are inanimate—possibly guide his fate? He's rejecting the idea of astrological influence, using this rhetorical question to express his despair and sense of helplessness after killing Tybalt.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: The Friar is telling Romeo he wants to calmly discuss his current situation. He uses the word "dispute" here to mean "reason" or "debate," and "estate" refers to Romeo's circumstances—specifically, his banishment. He is attempting to offer counsel and perspective to the distraught Romeo.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo insists the Friar cannot understand his pain because he hasn't experienced it himself. He lists his specific circumstances—youth, new marriage, murdering Tybalt, and banishment—to argue that only someone in his exact position would be driven to such extreme, grief-stricken actions. His final image of measuring his own "unmade grave" shows he already sees himself as dead due to the separation from Juliet.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: The Friar urgently tells Romeo to get up and hide because someone is knocking at the door. This creates immediate tension, as Romeo is a fugitive in Mantua for killing Tybalt and risks being discovered.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo is saying he will not leave unless his own sorrowful sighs surround him like a mist, hiding him from sight. This metaphor emphasizes his despair and desire to be invisible due to his grief over killing Tybalt and being banished. The knocking interrupts his lament, signaling the arrival of the Nurse.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: The Friar is urgently telling Romeo to hide because someone is at the door and he risks being captured. His frantic, interrupted commands show his panic and the immediate danger Romeo is in. The Nurse then shouts from outside, identifying herself and revealing she brings news from Juliet, which escalates the tension as her arrival signals a critical update.

speaker: NURSE
content: The Nurse is calling from outside Friar Laurence's cell, urgently demanding entry. She immediately reveals she has come from Juliet to establish her authority and the importance of her message.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: The Friar greets Romeo, who has just arrived at his cell after killing Tybalt. This simple welcome establishes the scene for their urgent, private conversation about the consequences of Romeo's banishment.

speaker: NURSE
content: The Nurse is frantically asking Friar Laurence where Romeo is. She calls him "my lady's lord" to emphasize that he is Juliet's husband. Her urgency stems from the fact that Romeo has just killed Tybalt and been banished, and she needs to find him for Juliet.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: The Friar describes Romeo collapsed on the floor, so overwhelmed with weeping that he is incapacitated. The Nurse immediately draws a parallel, noting that Juliet is in the exact same state of desperate, weeping misery. She scolds Romeo, telling him to be a man and stand up for Juliet's sake, and questions why he would fall into such a dramatic, despairing fit.

speaker: NURSE
content: The Nurse tells Romeo that Juliet is in the same miserable state he is—crying uncontrollably. She urges him to stop his dramatic moaning and stand up like a man for Juliet's sake, arguing that his despair is pointless and unhelpful.

speaker: ROMEO
content: The Nurse arrives to inform Romeo of his punishment—exile—for killing Tybalt. Her opening line is a conventional expression of grief, meaning that death is the ultimate fate for everyone, but here it also foreshadows the tragedy to come.

speaker: NURSE
content: The Nurse is telling Friar Laurence that Juliet is so overwhelmed with grief over Romeo's banishment that she is inconsolable and acting as if she's dying. She is dramatically emphasizing the severity of the situation to the Friar, urging him to find a solution.

speaker: ROMEO
content:
Romeo is frantic, asking the Nurse if Juliet now sees him as a murderer for killing her cousin Tybalt. He fears their new marriage is ruined ("cancell'd love") because he has stained their happiness with blood nearly as close to her as her own.

The Nurse reports that Juliet is overwhelmed, alternating between collapsing in grief and crying out for both Tybalt and Romeo, showing her torn loyalties and despair.

speaker: NURSE
content: The Nurse describes Juliet's frantic, alternating grief over Tybalt's death and Romeo's banishment. Her physical collapse and sudden starts show she is overwhelmed, shifting between sorrow for her slain cousin and despair for her exiled husband. This paints a vivid picture of her emotional turmoil and inner conflict.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo is distraught that his name, "Montague," was the weapon that emotionally wounded Juliet, just as his hand killed her cousin Tybalt. He desperately asks Friar Laurence to point out where in his body this hated name resides so he can destroy it by suicide, physically acting out his self-loathing by drawing his sword.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content:
Friar Lawrence is scolding Romeo for his emotional collapse after killing Tybalt and being banished. He argues that Romeo is acting inconsistently with his identity as a man, a lover, and a rational being—his tears are "womanish," his rage "beastly," and his threats of suicide a betrayal of his love for Juliet. The Friar insists Romeo is squandering his blessings: his body, love, and intellect, which he possesses in abundance but fails to use properly.

He then shifts to listing reasons Romeo should be happy: Juliet is alive, he killed Tybalt in self-defense, and his punishment is exile, not death. The Friar urges him to see Juliet secretly before fleeing to Mantua, where they can plan for a future reconciliation. He instructs the Nurse to prepare Juliet for Romeo’s visit and ensure the household goes to bed early.

speaker: NURSE
content: The Nurse is so impressed by Friar Laurence's wise advice that she wishes she could stay longer to listen. She then assures Romeo that she will inform Juliet he is coming to her.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo is telling the Nurse to tell Juliet to prepare to scold him for killing Tybalt. The Nurse then gives Romeo a ring from Juliet, urging him to hurry because it is getting late. This ring is a token of Juliet's continued love and her message for Romeo to come to her.

speaker: NURSE
content: The Nurse brings Romeo a ring from Juliet, signaling that she still loves him despite his banishment and Tybalt's death. Her urgent tone encourages him to visit Juliet quickly, as their time together is limited.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo is responding to the Nurse's news that Juliet still loves him despite his killing of Tybalt. His despair briefly lifts because he learns his banishment hasn't cost him her affection. This line shows his volatile emotions, as he swings from suicidal grief to sudden hope based on Juliet's continued loyalty.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: The Friar is urgently telling Romeo to flee Verona immediately—either before the night watch is posted or at dawn in disguise—and to live in Mantua. He promises to send Romeo’s servant to keep him updated with any good news from Verona, then bids him a hasty farewell because it’s late and they must part.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo tells the Friar that the overwhelming happiness of his marriage to Juliet makes any sorrow from their parting feel short-lived. He is saying that his joy is so immense it overshadows the brief grief of saying goodbye. This line emphasizes the intensity of his love, even in the face of his sudden banishment.

speaker: CAPULET
content: Capulet is apologizing to Paris for not yet having spoken to Juliet about their marriage plans, explaining that Tybalt's death has left the household in mourning. He then abruptly ends the conversation, saying it's too late for Juliet to come down and that he is too tired to continue, effectively postponing the discussion.

speaker: PARIS
content: Paris is telling Lady Capulet that the recent death of Tybalt makes this a sorrowful time, not a suitable one for courtship. He politely ends the conversation and asks her to pass his regards to Juliet.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
content: Lady Capulet is telling Capulet she will speak with Juliet in the morning about marrying Paris. She explains that Juliet is currently shut away in her room, overwhelmed by grief over Tybalt's death, and thus unavailable for conversation tonight.

speaker: CAPULET
content: Capulet is promising Paris that he will offer Juliet's hand in marriage, confidently asserting that she will obey his decision. He then instructs his wife to inform Juliet about the planned wedding this coming Wednesday, but he pauses to check what day it currently is.

speaker: PARIS
content: Paris is informing Lord Capulet that the current day is Monday. This detail is crucial because Capulet is about to propose that Paris marry Juliet in just a few days, on Thursday, setting a frantic pace for the tragic events to come.

speaker: CAPULET
content: Capulet is hastily arranging Juliet's marriage to Paris, settling on Thursday. He wants a small, quiet ceremony because Tybalt has just died; a large celebration would seem disrespectful to their slain kinsman. He asks Paris if he approves of the quick date and modest plans.

speaker: PARIS
content: Paris is eager to marry Juliet and wishes the wedding could happen immediately. He expresses this impatience to Lord Capulet, hoping to speed up their arranged marriage.

speaker: CAPULET
content: Capulet tells his wife to inform Juliet that her marriage to Paris is set for Thursday. He then calls for a servant to light his way to bed, noting how late it has become—so late it will soon be morning. This hasty decision, made without Juliet's consent, sets up the tragic conflict to follow.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet insists it is still night, not morning, so Romeo need not leave yet. She claims the bird they heard was the nightingale (which sings at night) rather than the lark (which heralds dawn), trying to prolong their time together. This shows her desperation to delay their separation after their secret wedding night.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo insists that the morning light means he must leave Juliet immediately to avoid being caught and executed. He poetically describes dawn's arrival to emphasize their time together is over, creating urgency and foreshadowing his tragic fate if he stays.

speaker: JULIET
content: Julet insists the light isn't morning sun but a meteor, which she imagines as a torchbearer to light Romeo's path to Mantua. She uses this fanciful explanation to persuade him he doesn't need to leave yet, desperately trying to prolong their time together before his banishment.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo insists he would rather be captured and killed than leave Juliet, denying that the morning light is dawn and the bird's song is the lark's. He claims it is still night, showing his desperation to stay with her despite the danger. His willingness to die if Juliet wishes it underscores his devotion and the tragic recklessness of their love.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet urgently tells Romeo to flee because the lark's song signals daybreak, which means he will be caught and killed if he stays. She bitterly contrasts the traditional belief that the lark sings sweetly with her own experience of its "harsh" notes, which forces them to separate. The "hunt's-up" is a morning song used to wake hunters, here metaphorically chasing Romeo away as daylight increases.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo observes that as daylight increases, their troubles grow more severe. He uses this paradox to express that their situation is worsening with the morning's arrival. This line emphasizes the deepening conflict between their secret love and the harsh reality of their families' feud.

speaker: NURSE
content: The Nurse is addressing Juliet's mother, Lady Capulet, with a formal and respectful title. This simple address establishes the Nurse's subordinate position in the household and sets the scene for their following conversation.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet calls for the Nurse, who urgently warns her that Lady Capulet is approaching her bedroom. The Nurse adds that day has broken, cautioning Juliet to be careful and alert since Romeo must flee before he is discovered.

speaker: NURSE
content: The Nurse urgently warns Juliet that her mother is approaching, so she must be cautious and alert. This creates immediate tension, as Lady Capulet must not discover Romeo's presence in her daughter's room.

speaker: JULIET
content: Julet is telling the dawn to enter through her window, symbolically letting in the day, while also wishing for Romeo's life to depart so he can escape before he is caught and killed. This line uses a poetic antithesis to express her desperate conflict: she wants the safety of night to continue for her new husband, but the dangerous reality of day is arriving.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo is saying goodbye to Juliet after their secret wedding night, promising one final kiss before climbing down from her balcony. His descent marks their painful separation, as he must flee Verona to avoid execution for killing Tybalt. This moment heightens the tragedy by showing their desperate love amid forced parting.

speaker: JULIET
content: Julet is expressing her intense longing for Romeo after their secret wedding night, fearing their separation will feel unbearably long. She exaggerates time's passage—"in a minute there are many days"—to show how each moment without him will stretch into what feels like years. This highlights her youthful passion and foreshadows the agony of their impending separation.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo is reassuring Juliet that he will send messages to her whenever possible. He promises not to miss any chance to communicate his affection and stay connected despite their separation.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet anxiously asks Romeo if they will ever see each other again, revealing her deep fear and foreboding about their future. She is worried that their forced separation after his banishment will be permanent. This line highlights her desperation and the tragic uncertainty hanging over their relationship.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo is reassuring Juliet that their current sorrows will one day become the source of sweet stories they will tell each other in the future. He uses this hopeful perspective to comfort her as they part at dawn, suggesting that their present suffering will eventually enrich their love.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet has a sudden, ominous premonition as she watches Romeo leave. She vividly imagines him lying dead at the bottom of a tomb, and she notes that he looks pale, which intensifies her feeling of dread. This foreshadows the play's tragic conclusion and reveals her deep anxiety about their future.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo is telling Juliet that she looks as pale and sorrowful as he feels, suggesting their shared grief is physically draining them. The phrase "dry sorrow drinks our blood" means that sadness consumes their vitality. He then bids her a final, urgent farewell as he must leave.

speaker: JULIET
content: Julet is addressing Fortune as if it were a fickle person, questioning why it would be associated with someone as faithful as Romeo. She paradoxically wishes for Fortune to be fickle so that it will not keep Romeo away from her for long and will quickly return him to Verona. This shows her desperation and hope for his swift return from exile.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
content: Lady Capulet is calling from outside Juliet's room, checking if she is awake. This establishes the morning setting and her motherly concern, while also creating tension because the audience knows Juliet has just spent her wedding night with Romeo.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet is startled by Lady Capulet's unexpected arrival at her bedroom so late at night or early in the morning. She wonders aloud what unusual reason could have brought her mother to visit at this hour, immediately sensing that something is wrong.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
content: Lady Capulet is startled by Juliet's visible distress, which is actually grief over Romeo's banishment, though her mother mistakes it for sorrow over Tybalt's death. She asks this question to find out why her daughter is so upset, beginning a conversation where she will unknowingly deepen Juliet's anguish by announcing the arranged marriage to Paris.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet tells her mother she feels unwell to avoid discussing marriage to Paris. This is a polite excuse that conceals her true distress over Romeo's banishment and her secret marriage.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
content: Lady Capulet is scolding Juliet for continuing to cry over Tybalt's death, suggesting that excessive mourning is pointless and foolish. She argues that while some grief demonstrates love, too much of it reveals a lack of intelligence. This is ironic because Juliet is actually weeping for Romeo's banishment, not Tybalt.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet is asking for permission to grieve the painful separation from Romeo, whom she believes she has lost. Her request reveals her deep sorrow and the emotional toll of their forced parting.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
content: Lady Capulet is telling Juliet that she will soon experience the pain of Tybalt's death, but she won't be mourning the person Juliet actually grieves for—Romeo. This is a dramatic irony, as Juliet is secretly weeping for Romeo's banishment, not Tybalt's death, while her mother believes she shares the family's hatred for Romeo.

speaker: JULIET
content: Julet is expressing her profound grief over Tybalt's death, saying she feels the loss so deeply that she must constantly weep for him. She calls him "the friend" to emphasize their familial bond, though her sorrow is complicated by the fact that Romeo—whom she cannot openly mourn—killed him.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
content: Lady Capulet is telling Juliet that she believes Juliet's tears are not truly for Tybalt's death, but because Romeo, the man who killed him, is still alive. She is trying to align Juliet with the family's desire for revenge, not realizing Juliet is secretly grieving for her banished husband. The word "slaughter'd" simply means killed.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet is responding to her mother, who has just cursed the "villain" Romeo for killing Tybalt. Juliet's question is a clever double entendre—she pretends not to know who her mother means, while secretly expressing horror at Romeo being called a villain. This allows her to defend Romeo without revealing her secret marriage or true feelings.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
content: Lady Capulet is cursing Romeo, whom she believes murdered her nephew Tybalt. She calls him a "villain" to express her hatred and desire for revenge. This shows her complete opposition to Juliet's secret marriage and sets up her later demand for Romeo's death.

speaker: JULIET
content: Julet is insisting that Romeo is not a villain, despite Tybalt's death, and she forgives him completely. However, she admits that his actions have caused her immense personal sorrow, creating a painful conflict between her love for him and her grief.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
content: Lady Capulet is telling Juliet that Romeo still lives, calling him a traitor and murderer for killing Tybalt. She believes justice won't be served until Romeo is dead. This directly contrasts with Juliet's secret grief over Romeo's banishment, showing the family's hatred that separates the lovers.

speaker: JULIET
content: Julet is telling her mother she wishes she could personally avenge Tybalt's death with her own hands. The word "venge" means to take revenge, and she's pretending to agree with Lady Capulet's anger while secretly referring to Romeo, whom she cannot harm. This is dramatic irony, as the audience knows her true feelings conflict with her words.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
content: Lady Capulet promises revenge on Romeo for killing Tybalt, telling Juliet to stop crying. She plans to send someone to Mantua to poison Romeo ("an unaccustom'd dram"), ensuring he dies and joins Tybalt in death, hoping this will satisfy Juliet's grief.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet is using double meanings to mislead her mother, who believes Juliet is grieving Tybalt. When she says she wants to see Romeo "dead," she secretly means in her bed, but her mother hears it as a wish for his death. Her talk of poisoning Romeo is a clever act to conceal her true love and loyalty for him, while outwardly appearing to seek revenge.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
content: Lady Capulet is telling Juliet she will arrange a marriage to Paris if Juliet can find a way to get out of her current situation. She then shifts to a cheerful tone to announce what she believes is good news.

speaker: JULIET
content: Julet is responding to her mother, who has just announced she has "joyful tidings." Juliet, who is secretly married to Romeo, hopes this means news of him. She politely asks her mother to share the news, using the formal "your ladyship" to show respect.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
content: Lady Capulet is telling Juliet that her father has thoughtfully arranged a surprise to cheer her up. She refers to Lord Capulet's plan for Juliet to marry Paris, which he believes will end her apparent grief over Tybalt's death. This is meant to present the marriage as a happy solution, though Juliet knows it will only worsen her distress.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet is asking her mother, Lady Capulet, which day she is referring to, pretending to be pleasantly curious. She has just heard her mother mention "Thursday" but feigns ignorance to avoid revealing her secret marriage to Romeo. This line shows Juliet's quick thinking as she tries to gather information while maintaining her deceptive composure.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
content: Lady Capulet informs Juliet that she will be married to Paris at Saint Peter's Church next Thursday morning. She describes Paris with flattering terms like "gallant" and "noble" to make the arranged marriage sound appealing. This announcement directly contradicts Juliet's secret marriage to Romeo, creating immediate and intense dramatic conflict.

speaker: JULIET
content: Julet emphatically swears she will not marry Paris, expressing shock at being rushed into marriage before even being courted. She defiantly tells her mother she refuses the wedding, then adds bitter irony by claiming she'd rather marry Romeo—whom the family believes she hates—knowing this will outrage them while secretly speaking the truth about her actual husband.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
content: Lady Capulet is warning Juliet that her father is approaching and sarcastically suggesting she deliver her refusal to marry Paris directly to him. She implies this will provoke Lord Capulet's anger, shifting responsibility for the confrontation onto Juliet. This heightens tension by setting up the imminent clash between Juliet and her authoritarian father.

speaker: CAPULET
content: Capulet is using elaborate metaphors to mock Juliet's excessive weeping over Tybalt's death. He compares her to a ship (bark) tossed in a stormy sea of her own tears, with her sighs as the wind, warning that this emotional tempest will overwhelm her. He then abruptly turns to his wife to ask if she has informed Juliet of their decision that she must marry Paris.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
content: Lady Capulet is telling Capulet that Juliet refuses his command to marry Paris. Her harsh wish that Juliet be "married to her grave" is a dramatic and cruel curse, meaning she'd rather see her daughter dead than be so disobedient. This shows her complete alignment with her husband's anger and her lack of maternal sympathy.

speaker: CAPULET
content: Capulet interrupts his wife, asking her to slow down and explain. He is shocked that Juliet is refusing the marriage to Paris, listing the benefits she should be grateful for. He sarcastically questions her lack of pride and gratitude, emphasizing that he has secured a highly suitable husband for her, whom he considers far above her own worth.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet is telling Romeo she isn't proud of their marriage, but she is grateful for it. She clarifies that she could never take pride in something she's been forced to hate—their union, due to the family feud—but she can still feel thankful for it because his intentions were loving. This shows her conflicted loyalty between her family and her secret husband.

speaker: CAPULET
content: Capulet is furiously mocking Juliet's contradictory words and defiant attitude. He commands her to prepare for her wedding to Paris this Thursday, threatening to drag her there by force if she refuses. His final insults—"green-sickness carrion," "baggage," and "tallow-face"—mock her pale complexion and call her worthless.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
content: "Fie, fie!" is an archaic exclamation of disgust or disapproval, like saying "Shame on you!" Lady Capulet is reacting with shock and anger to Juliet's refusal to marry Paris, interpreting her daughter's passionate grief (over Romeo's banishment) as irrational madness. She is scolding Juliet for defying her father's authority and the family's plans.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet kneels before her father, Lord Capulet, in a desperate plea for him to listen to her. She is humbling herself to beg for a moment of his patience, hoping to explain why she cannot marry Paris. This posture of submission starkly contrasts with her father's escalating rage in this confrontation.

speaker: CAPULET
content: Capulet furiously calls Juliet a "baggage" (burden) and a "hilding" (worthless person), commanding her to marry Paris on Thursday or be disowned. He tells her not to speak and admits his "fingers itch" to strike her, lamenting that his only child has become a curse. The Nurse immediately defends Juliet, boldly telling Capulet he is wrong to scold her so harshly.

speaker: NURSE
content: The Nurse is defending Juliet against her father's harsh scolding. She directly tells Lord Capulet that he is at fault for berating his daughter so severely.

speaker: CAPULET
content: Capulet is angrily dismissing the Nurse's attempt to reason with him about his daughter's marriage. He sarcastically calls her "my lady wisdom" and "prudence" to mock her advice, telling her to be quiet and go gossip with her friends instead. The Nurse's brief reply is a defensive claim that her words are not disrespectful or rebellious.

speaker: NURSE
content: The Nurse is defending herself against Juliet's accusation of disloyalty after she advises Juliet to marry Paris. She means she is not speaking against her duty or betraying the family. This marks her shift from being Juliet's confidante to siding with the Capulet household's practical plans.

speaker: CAPULET
content: Capulet is furiously mocking his daughter, Juliet, for refusing to marry Paris. His sarcastic exclamation "God ye good-en!" is an archaic way of saying "God give you good evening," which he uses to cruelly mimic her sorrowful state. When the Nurse tries to intervene, he immediately silences her, showing he will tolerate no opposition.

speaker: NURSE
content: The Nurse is interrupting a tense exchange between Juliet and her mother, who is demanding an answer about marrying Paris. She speaks up to defend Juliet or ease the mounting conflict, but Lady Capulet immediately silences her. This shows the Nurse's diminished power in the household now that she has advised Juliet to betray Romeo.

speaker: CAPULET
content: Capulet is angrily dismissing the Nurse, who has just spoken in Juliet's defense. He insults her by calling her a babbling old woman and tells her to save her serious advice ("gravity") for idle chatter over drinks with friends—implying her opinion is worthless here.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
content: Lady Capulet is telling her husband to calm down, calling him too angry or rash. She's trying to de-escalate the situation as he is furious with Juliet for refusing to marry Paris. This brief interjection shows her attempting to be a peacemaker in the heated family conflict.

speaker: CAPULET
content: Capulet is furious that Juliet refuses to marry Paris, whom he describes as an ideal, well-bred gentleman. He calls her a "puling fool" (a whining child) and a "mammet" (a doll or puppet) for rejecting this advantageous match. In a brutal ultimatum, he tells her she must consent to the wedding by Thursday or be disowned and left to beg or die in the streets.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet desperately appeals to her mother for compassion, asking if heaven can see her profound sorrow. She pleads not to be cast out and begs for a delay of the marriage—even just a week—or threatens that if forced, she will kill herself and share a tomb with Tybalt.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
content: Lady Capulet is refusing to speak to or help her daughter, Juliet, any further. She says this because she is furious that Juliet has disobeyed her and Lord Capulet by refusing to marry Paris. Her words are a final, cold dismissal, leaving Juliet completely isolated.

speaker: JULIET
content:
Juliet desperately asks the Nurse for advice on how to avoid marrying Paris, since she is already married to Romeo. She sees her situation as a cruel trick from heaven, as her marital vows are sacred and cannot be undone unless Romeo dies.

The Nurse responds by crudely advising Juliet to forget Romeo and marry Paris. She callously dismisses the banished Romeo as worthless compared to Paris and argues that since Juliet cannot be with Romeo, she should take the new match, which she insists is better.

speaker: NURSE
content: The Nurse bluntly tells Juliet that Romeo is banished and unlikely to return, so she should marry Paris. She crudely reverses her previous praise of Romeo, now calling him a "dishclout" (dishrag) compared to the "eagle"-like Paris. Her harsh conclusion is that Juliet's first marriage is useless since Romeo is as good as dead to her in Verona.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet is asking the Nurse if she truly believes what she just said. The Nurse swears she is speaking sincerely from her heart and soul, using "beshrew" (a mild curse) to emphasize her honesty. This confirms her earnest support for Juliet's secret marriage to Romeo.

speaker: NURSE
content: The Nurse is swearing an oath that she speaks from her deepest feelings. She means that if her words are not true, a curse should fall upon both her soul and her heart. This is her emphatic way of assuring Juliet that she is being completely sincere.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet is sarcastically agreeing with the Nurse's earlier suggestion that she should marry Paris now that Romeo is banished. Her terse "Amen" is a bitter, dismissive response, showing she rejects the advice entirely. The Nurse's startled "What?" indicates her surprise at Juliet's sharp and uncharacteristic tone.

speaker: NURSE
content: The Nurse is reacting with shock and disbelief to Juliet's sudden change of heart about Romeo. Her single-word question expresses her confusion and serves to prompt Juliet to explain her harsh new opinion of her husband.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet is being sarcastic, telling the Nurse that her advice to marry Paris has been anything but comforting. She then lies, saying she's going to Friar Laurence's cell for confession to cover her real plan to seek his help. The Nurse approves, believing Juliet is wisely submitting to her father's will.

speaker: NURSE
content: The Nurse agrees to help Juliet by going to find Romeo and tell him to come for their wedding night. Her quick exit shows she is acting immediately on this plan, demonstrating her loyalty and eagerness to assist the young lovers.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet curses the Nurse as a damned, wicked demon for advising her to break her marriage vow to Romeo and marry Paris instead. She severs their close relationship, declaring she will seek Friar Laurence's help—and if no solution is found, she has the power to take her own life.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: Friar Lawrence expresses surprise at the suddenness of the wedding, noting there are only two days to prepare. His concern highlights the impractical rush of the plan, setting up his need to devise a desperate solution.

speaker: PARIS
content: Paris is telling Friar Laurence that Lord Capulet has arranged his marriage to Juliet, and he is not reluctant to go along with his father-in-law's rushed plans. This shows Paris's eagerness to please the Capulets and his complete unawareness of Juliet's true feelings.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: The Friar expresses concern that Juliet's consent is uncertain, making the plan risky. He dislikes this unpredictability and feels uneasy about proceeding without her agreement.

speaker: PARIS
content: Paris explains to Friar Laurence that Juliet is grieving excessively for Tybalt, which has prevented him from courting her properly. He says Capulet believes that marriage will distract her from her sorrow and provide companionship to help her recover, which is why the wedding is being rushed.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: Friar Lawrence is expressing private concern that the marriage is being delayed, though he doesn't know the reason. He immediately shifts attention by announcing Juliet's arrival, ending his private thought to address Paris directly.

speaker: PARIS
content: Paris greets Juliet with cheerful formality, addressing her as his future bride. He uses the conventional language of courtship, unaware that Juliet has come to Friar Laurence in deep distress to avoid this very marriage.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet is telling Paris that she might be happy to be called his wife only after they are actually married. She is being evasive and polite, concealing her true feelings and her secret marriage to Romeo. This shows her forced composure in a tense situation where she is desperate to avoid this arranged marriage.

speaker: PARIS
content: Paris is insisting that his marriage to Juliet must happen this coming Thursday. He is speaking to Friar Laurence, trying to confirm the wedding date that Lord Capulet has arranged. His repetition of "must be" shows he is determined and sees the marriage as an unavoidable certainty.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet is expressing a fatalistic resignation to her desperate situation. She means that whatever is destined to happen will happen, showing her acceptance of the Friar's dangerous plan to fake her death. This line underscores her resolve to take extreme action rather than be forced to marry Paris.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: Friar Lawrence is confirming that Juliet's statement about preferring death over marrying Paris is a reliable and serious declaration. He uses "certain text" to mean her words are a trustworthy source, showing he believes she is absolutely resolved. This leads him to propose his risky plan, trusting her desperation and commitment.

speaker: PARIS
content: Paris is asking Juliet if she has come to Friar Laurence to confess her sins. He is unaware of her secret marriage to Romeo and still believes she is his own intended bride. This question highlights the public misunderstanding of Juliet's situation and her private desperation.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet is evading Paris's question about whether she loves him. She says that if she were to answer directly, she would have to admit something she doesn't want to say. This polite but evasive reply shows her desperation to avoid this arranged marriage without revealing her secret marriage to Romeo.

speaker: PARIS
content: Paris is urging Juliet to admit her supposed affection for him to her father, Lord Capulet. He believes this will help smooth the way for their arranged marriage, which he sees as a joyful event.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet is confessing her love for Paris to Friar Laurence, but she is being deliberately deceptive. She knows the Friar believes she is speaking of Paris, but she is actually referring to Romeo, using this double meaning to set up her desperate plea for help in avoiding the marriage.

speaker: PARIS
content: Paris is reassuring Juliet that she will agree to marry him because he believes she loves him. He is speaking confidently, assuming her feelings match his own, which adds dramatic irony since the audience knows Juliet is already married to Romeo and deeply distressed by this arranged match.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet is telling Friar Laurence that if she praises Romeo in his absence, her words will carry more weight and sincerity than if she said them directly to him. She implies that praise given when the person isn't present is less likely to be flattery and therefore more valuable.

speaker: PARIS
content: Paris observes that Juliet's face is swollen and disfigured from her constant crying. He is attempting to be sympathetic, but his comment is a superficial observation of her grief, which he mistakenly believes is for her dead cousin Tybalt.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet is dismissing her own crying as pointless, saying her grief was already unbearable even before she started weeping. She means her tears haven't actually helped relieve her suffering—they've only added to her misery.

speaker: PARIS
content: Paris is telling Juliet that her sorrowful words are more harmful to her face than tears would be. He believes her grief is damaging her beauty, and he is trying to comfort her by suggesting that verbal expressions of sadness are worse for her appearance than crying would be.

speaker: JULIET
content: Julet is telling Friar Laurence that she cannot be accused of slander because she is merely stating a true fact about herself. By saying she spoke "to my face," she clarifies that she was speaking about herself directly, not gossiping about someone else. This is her justification for her earlier blunt confession that she wishes to die if she cannot avoid marrying Paris.

speaker: PARIS
content: Paris is accusing Juliet of slandering her own face—which he considers his property since they are betrothed—by crying and making it look sorrowful. He believes her display of grief dishonors the happy appearance she should have as his future wife.

speaker: JULIET
content: Julet is telling Friar Laurence that Paris's claim of marriage may be true, but she cannot accept it because her heart belongs to Romeo. She then politely asks if the Friar is available to speak, or if she should wait until the evening church service.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: Friar Lawrence politely tells Juliet he is available to speak with her, calling her "pensive daughter" to acknowledge her troubled state. He then asks Lord Capulet and Paris to leave them alone so they can have a private conversation.

speaker: PARIS
content: Paris politely excuses himself for interrupting Juliet's prayers. He reminds her that he will wake her early on Thursday for their wedding, then bids her farewell with a symbolic kiss. This emphasizes his formality and the looming, fixed date of the marriage, which intensifies the pressure on Juliet.

speaker: JULIET
content: Julet is desperately asking the Friar to shut the door so they can be alone. She then pleads for him to join her in mourning, expressing her utter despair that her situation is beyond any hope, remedy, or assistance.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: Friar Lawrence is telling Juliet he already knows about her distress over the forced marriage. He admits her situation is so difficult it pushes him beyond the limits of his own cleverness. He confirms he has heard she must marry Paris this coming Thursday and that nothing can delay it.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet demands the Friar offer a solution to avoid marrying Paris, or she will kill herself with the dagger she is holding. She insists that since he joined her and Romeo in marriage, she would rather die than be unfaithful. Her desperate ultimatum pressures the Friar to immediately provide the risky potion plan.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: Friar Lawrence is telling Juliet that he has a dangerous plan to prevent her marriage to Paris, which will require as much courage as suicide. He suggests that if she is willing to kill herself to avoid shame, she might instead be brave enough to simulate death. He offers her a potion that will make her appear dead, allowing her to escape her predicament.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet is telling Friar Laurence she would rather face terrifying dangers than be forced to marry Paris. She lists horrifying scenarios—like leaping from a tower, being chained with bears, or hiding among corpses—that would normally make her tremble with fear. She insists she would endure any of these horrors without hesitation to remain a faithful wife to Romeo.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: Friar Lawrence is giving Juliet a sleeping potion that will make her appear dead for 42 hours. He instructs her to take it the night before her wedding to Paris, after which she will be placed in the Capulet tomb. The Friar will then inform Romeo, who will retrieve her when she awakens so they can escape to Mantua together.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet is demanding the vial from Friar Laurence, showing her desperation and resolve to escape her arranged marriage to Paris. She dismisses any talk of fear, emphasizing her willingness to face any horror—even death—rather than break her vow to Romeo.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: Friar Lawrence is reassuring Juliet that he will immediately send a messenger to Mantua with a letter explaining their plan to Romeo. He urges her to be brave and stick to their agreement, promising swift action to ensure Romeo is informed. This is part of their secret scheme to reunite her with Romeo after she takes the sleeping potion.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet is steeling herself to drink the Friar's potion, asking for courage to go through with the desperate plan. Her farewell to her father is ironic, as she is speaking to the empty room, knowing her family will soon believe her dead.

speaker: CAPULET
content: Capulet is giving orders to a servant, telling him to invite all the people whose names are written on a list. This instruction shows Capulet's eagerness and haste as he prepares for Juliet's sudden wedding to Paris.

speaker: SECOND SERVANT
content: The servant assures Capulet that none of the cooks are dishonest, promising to test them by seeing if they taste the food with their fingers. This is a practical check for greed or poor hygiene among the kitchen staff. His comment adds a moment of mundane, everyday detail that contrasts with the high-stakes secret plans unfolding around Juliet.

speaker: CAPULET
content: Capulet is impatiently asking how the servant has tested the cooks, implying they are taking too long. The servant responds with a proverb, meaning a bad cook won't taste his own food; he's saying any cook unwilling to sample his own cooking is not skilled enough to work for the Capulets.

speaker: SECOND SERVANT
content: This servant uses a proverb to say that a cook who won't taste his own food is a bad one. He applies this logic to hiring, stating he won't keep anyone who isn't willing to enjoy their own work, meaning he wants servants who are as self-indulgent as he is.

speaker: CAPULET
content: Capulet is urgently dismissing someone, likely a servant, to carry out his orders. His abrupt command shows he is in a hurry and expects immediate obedience, reflecting his authoritative nature and the rushed preparations for Juliet's wedding.

speaker: NURSE
content: The Nurse is politely agreeing with Juliet, using "forsooth" to mean "indeed" or "truly." Her simple, respectful reply shows she is following Juliet's instructions without question, maintaining the appearance of normalcy as they prepare for the wedding that Juliet intends to avoid.

speaker: CAPULET
content: Capulet is expressing hope that Paris's visit might improve Juliet's mood, since she has been grieving excessively over Tybalt's death. He then angrily dismisses her behavior as that of a stubborn, ill-tempered girl—"harlotry" here is an insult meaning a worthless woman, not a literal prostitute.

speaker: NURSE
content: The Nurse is telling the Capulets that Juliet is returning from confession looking cheerful. She believes this means Juliet has agreed to marry Paris, which is a ruse; Juliet is actually pretending to be obedient after secretly planning her fake death with Friar Laurence.

speaker: CAPULET
content: Capulet is scolding Juliet for being out without his permission, using the old-fashioned word "gadding" to mean wandering idly or frivolously. His tone is sharp and controlling, showing his authority and frustration with her independent behavior.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet is pretending to apologize to her parents for refusing to marry Paris. She claims Friar Lawrence has instructed her to beg forgiveness and promises complete obedience going forward. This is a calculated performance to make her family believe she has surrendered, ensuring they won't suspect her plan to fake her death.

speaker: CAPULET
content: Capulet is ordering his servants to fetch Paris and inform him that Juliet has agreed to marry him. He then declares his intention to have the wedding take place the very next morning. The phrase "this knot knit up" is a metaphor for finalizing the marriage.

speaker: JULIET
content: Julet tells her father she met Paris at Friar Laurence's cell and behaved appropriately toward him, showing the modesty expected of a young woman. She is lying to convince Capulet she is now obedient and willing to marry Paris, ensuring her plan to fake her death can proceed without suspicion.

speaker: CAPULET
content: Capulet is overjoyed that Juliet has apparently agreed to marry Paris. He immediately orders a servant to fetch Paris so the wedding can proceed, and he praises Friar Laurence, believing the Friar is responsible for Juliet's change of heart and has done a great service for their family.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet asks the Nurse to help her choose clothes and accessories for her wedding to Paris the next day. She uses the word "closet" to mean a private room, and "ornaments" refers to her wedding attire. This is a ruse—Juliet is actually preparing to take the Friar's potion and feign death, not to get married.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
content: Lady Capulet is telling Juliet that the wedding to Paris will not happen until Thursday, suggesting there is plenty of time to prepare. This is ironic because Juliet has already taken the potion and is secretly planning to fake her death that very night, making her mother's calm assurance tragically misplaced.

speaker: CAPULET
content: Capulet is instructing the Nurse to accompany Juliet as she leaves to prepare for her wedding. He then announces that the ceremony will take place the very next day, showing his eagerness to proceed with the marriage to Paris.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
content: Lady Capulet is telling the Nurse that they will not have enough time to prepare everything for the wedding feast, as it is already almost evening. She is expressing her anxiety about the lack of preparation for the celebration she believes will happen the next morning.

speaker: CAPULET
content: Capulet is reassuring his wife that he will take charge of the wedding preparations himself. He says he will stay up to oversee things and will personally visit Paris to finalize plans for the next day. His final line reveals he is overjoyed because he believes Juliet has obediently agreed to marry Paris.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet is politely dismissing the Nurse so she can be alone to take the sleeping potion. She claims she needs to say prayers ("orisons") to improve her troubled and sinful situation, which is a cover story to hide her true, dangerous plan from the Nurse.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
content: Lady Capulet is checking on Juliet before her wedding to Paris, asking if she needs assistance with preparations. She uses "ho" as an attention-getting interjection, not unlike saying "hey there." This shows her performing expected maternal duties, though their relationship remains formal and distant.

speaker: JULIET
content: Julet is politely telling her mother she has already chosen the clothes and accessories appropriate for her wedding. She asks to be left alone and suggests the Nurse stay with Lady Capulet, pretending concern about the sudden wedding preparations to avoid suspicion about her real plan to take the potion.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
content: Lady Capulet is bidding her daughter goodnight, telling Juliet to go to bed and rest because she looks tired. This is a moment of dramatic irony, as the audience knows Juliet is feigning tiredness to be alone and take the sleeping potion.

speaker: JULIET
content: Juliet is voicing her terror before drinking the potion, imagining every possible disaster: that it might be poison, that it won't work at all, or that she will wake up too early in the tomb and go mad from the horror of her surroundings. Her fears culminate in a hallucination of Tybalt's ghost, but she overcomes this panic, toasts Romeo, and drinks.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
content: Lady Capulet is urgently directing the Nurse to gather more ingredients for the wedding feast preparations. The Nurse's reply indicates that the kitchen staff is also requesting specific fruits—dates and quinces—for the pastry cooks, highlighting the bustling activity and last-minute haste in the Capulet household.

speaker: NURSE
content: The Nurse is bustling about, giving orders for the wedding feast preparations. She mentions that the cooks are being called to bring "dates and quinces" (types of fruit) to the pastry kitchen, which shows the busy, festive atmosphere in the Capulet household as they prepare for Juliet's marriage to Paris.

speaker: CAPULET
content: Capulet is bustling about, urgently preparing for Juliet's wedding feast. He notes it's 3 a.m. and tells the servants to spare no expense on the food. The Nurse then sharply tells him to go to bed, calling him a "cot-quean" (a man who meddles in women's work), warning he'll be sick from staying up all night.

speaker: NURSE
content: The Nurse is scolding the Capulet servant for fussing like a housewife ("cot-quean") and staying up all night. She tells him to go to bed, warning that he will be sick tomorrow from staying awake so late.

speaker: CAPULET
content: Capulet is dismissing his wife's concern that he might be tired from staying up all night preparing for the wedding. He boasts that he has stayed awake for less important reasons in the past without any ill effects, showing his energetic and domineering nature as he takes charge of the frantic preparations.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
content: Lady Capulet is accusing her husband of having been a womanizer in his youth, calling him a "mouse-hunt," an old term for a cat that hunts mice, here meaning a pursuer of women. She declares that she will now keep a close watch on him to prevent him from such behavior. This sharp remark reveals her bitterness and distrust, adding tension to their interaction on what is supposed to be their daughter's wedding day.

speaker: CAPULET
content: Capulet is scolding the Nurse for being overly protective and suspicious, calling her a "jealous-hood" (an old term for a jealous person). He's impatient and dismissive, wanting her to stop fussing so the wedding preparations for Juliet can proceed without interruption.

speaker: FIRST SERVANT
content: The servant is telling Capulet that he has brought items for the cook, but he doesn't know the specifics of what they are. This line highlights the frantic, disorganized preparations for Juliet's wedding, creating a sense of bustling activity that contrasts sharply with the tragic reality of the situation.

speaker: CAPULET
content: Capulet is urgently directing his servants to prepare for Juliet's wedding to Paris. His repeated command emphasizes the frantic, bustling atmosphere in the household as they rush to get everything ready for the ceremony they believe is about to take place.

speaker: SECOND SERVANT
content: The servant is boasting that he can find firewood without needing to ask Peter for help. His "head" refers to his own intelligence and resourcefulness. This brief exchange shows the bustling, efficient preparations in the Capulet household for Juliet's wedding.

speaker: CAPULET
content: Capulet is cheerfully ordering the household to prepare for Juliet's wedding to Paris. He hears music signaling Paris's arrival and urgently calls for the Nurse to wake and dress the bride, showing his excitement and haste as the wedding day begins.

speaker: NURSE
content: The Nurse is trying to wake Juliet, who is feigning death from the Friar's potion. She playfully scolds her for sleeping in, joking that she should get her rest now because Paris will keep her awake on their wedding night. Her tone shifts from teasing to panic when Juliet doesn't respond, leading her to realize Juliet appears dead and she cries out for help.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
content: Lady Capulet hears the Nurse's cries and urgently asks what is happening. The Nurse responds with a dramatic exclamation of grief, immediately signaling that something terrible has occurred.

speaker: NURSE
content: The Nurse cries out in despair upon discovering Juliet's seemingly lifeless body. Her exclamation underscores the immediate shock and grief of the scene, marking the tragic turn where the family believes Juliet is truly dead.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
content: Lady Capulet asks what's wrong, and the Nurse's frantic exclamation signals that something terrible has happened. "Heavy day" means a sorrowful or grievous day, indicating she has just discovered Juliet apparently dead.

speaker: NURSE
content: The Nurse cries out in shock and grief upon discovering Juliet, who appears to be dead. Her exclamation "O heavy day!" expresses her deep sorrow and the weight of the tragedy she believes has occurred.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
content: Lady Capulet cries out in despair upon finding Juliet seemingly dead. She desperately calls for Juliet to wake up, believing her daughter is her only reason for living. Her frantic commands for help show her immediate panic and grief.

speaker: CAPULET
content: Capulet is impatiently ordering the Nurse to bring Juliet downstairs because Paris, her intended husband, has arrived for their wedding. The Nurse responds with horrified exclamations, declaring that Juliet is dead.

speaker: NURSE
content: The Nurse is crying out in shock and grief, announcing Juliet's apparent death to the household. Her repetition of "dead" and "deceas'd" emphasizes the finality of the situation and her own horrified disbelief.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
content: Lady Capulet cries out in despair, believing Juliet has died from grief over Tybalt. Her repetition of "she's dead" emphasizes her shock and immediate acceptance of this tragic loss. This exclamation begins the household's collective lamentation over Juliet's seemingly lifeless body.

speaker: CAPULET
content: Capulet discovers Juliet's seemingly lifeless body and describes the physical signs of death: her coldness, lack of circulation, and rigidity. He then uses a metaphor comparing her to a beautiful flower killed by an unexpected frost, emphasizing the tragedy of her youth and apparent untimely death.

speaker: NURSE
content: The Nurse cries out in despair upon discovering Juliet's seemingly lifeless body. She expresses overwhelming grief and shock at the apparent tragedy, immediately alerting the household to the dire situation.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
content: Lady Capulet cries out in despair over what she believes is Juliet's death. Her exclamation expresses the overwhelming grief and tragedy of the moment, as she sees her daughter lying lifeless.

speaker: CAPULET
content: Capulet is overwhelmed with grief, believing Juliet has died. He personifies Death as having stolen her away to cause him sorrow, and now it's silencing him, rendering him unable to express his anguish.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: The Friar arrives expecting to perform Juliet's wedding to Paris, unaware she has taken the potion and appears dead. His opening question establishes the dramatic irony of the situation, as the audience knows the tragic truth he is about to discover.

speaker: CAPULET
content: Capulet personifies Death as Juliet's groom, saying she has been "deflowered" (a metaphor for losing her virginity) by dying the night before her wedding. He bitterly declares that Death is now his heir and son-in-law, to whom he will leave everything, as life itself now belongs to Death.

speaker: PARIS
content: Paris expresses his shock and disappointment upon arriving for his wedding to Juliet, only to find her seemingly dead. He had been eagerly anticipating this day, and the tragic sight before him is the opposite of the joyful morning he expected.

speaker: LADY CAPULET
content: Lady Capulet expresses her profound grief over Juliet's apparent death, emphasizing that her daughter was her only source of joy and comfort. She personifies death as a cruel force that has violently stolen her sole happiness. The Nurse then echoes this despair, repeating "woeful day" to amplify the shared anguish and dramatic irony of the scene.

speaker: NURSE
content: The Nurse is crying out in despair because she believes Juliet is dead. She repeats "woeful day" and "hateful day" to emphasize her shock and grief, using hyperbole to call it the worst day she has ever seen. This immediate, emotional reaction helps convey the household's devastation at finding Juliet seemingly lifeless.

speaker: PARIS
content: Paris laments Juliet's apparent death, listing the ways Death has wronged her: deceived, separated from him, harmed, and killed. He personifies Death as a cruel enemy who has stolen her away. His final cry expresses that his love for her now exists only in death, not in life.

speaker: CAPULET
content: Capulet is lamenting over Juliet's seemingly lifeless body, expressing his profound grief and despair. He personifies the timing of her death as an unwelcome intruder that has ruined their wedding celebration, then shifts to a heartbreaking realization that his daughter—and with her, all his happiness—is gone.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: The Friar scolds the Capulets for mourning Juliet's supposed death, arguing they should rejoice instead. He claims their grief is selfish since Juliet has achieved eternal life in heaven—the very "advancement" they wanted for her in marriage. He insists they follow funeral customs, explaining that while natural sorrow is understandable, reason should recognize her blessed state.

speaker: CAPULET
content: Capulet is lamenting how every joyful preparation for Juliet's wedding has been transformed into something for her funeral. He contrasts each element: festive music becomes tolling bells, wedding food becomes a funeral meal, and hymns turn into mournful songs. This emphasizes the sudden, tragic reversal of celebration into mourning.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: The Friar is commanding the grieving family to stop mourning and prepare for Juliet's burial. He suggests their sorrow is a punishment from heaven for some past wrong, and they should not anger the heavens further by resisting this fate. This speech maintains the ruse of Juliet's death while urging the family to proceed with the funeral plans.

speaker: FIRST MUSICIAN
content: The First Musician jokes that since the wedding is now a funeral, they can pack up their instruments and leave. He is speaking to his fellow musicians, suggesting there is no longer any need for their festive music. This line provides a moment of dark, practical humor, contrasting with the household's grief.

speaker: NURSE
content: The Nurse is telling the musicians to put away their instruments because this is a sorrowful occasion. She is trying to quiet them out of respect for what the household believes is Juliet's death.

speaker: FIRST MUSICIAN
content: The First Musician is responding to the Nurse's earlier complaints about their music, sarcastically agreeing that the situation could be improved. His remark is a dry, witty comment made to his fellow musicians after the Nurse has left the room. The entrance of Peter then shifts the scene's focus, as he will proceed to banter with the musicians.

speaker: PETER
content: Peter urgently demands the musicians play the cheerful tune "Heart's Ease" to relieve his overwhelming grief over Juliet's apparent death. The First Musician questions this request, finding it inappropriate to play a happy song during a time of mourning.

speaker: FIRST MUSICIAN
content: The musician questions why they should play the cheerful tune "Heart's Ease" at a time of mourning, since Juliet is believed to be dead. This highlights the jarring contrast between the festive music and the tragic situation, emphasizing the musicians' practical, somewhat detached perspective amid the family's grief.

speaker: PETER
content: Peter is asking the musicians to play a cheerful tune to lift his spirits, using a metaphor that his own heart is playing a sad song. The First Musician refuses, saying it's inappropriate to play music at such a sorrowful time.

speaker: FIRST MUSICIAN
content: The musician uses "dump" to mean a sad tune, refusing to play because the household believes Juliet is dead. He says this is not the right moment for music, as everyone is in mourning.

speaker: PETER
content: Peter is frustrated because the musicians refuse to play a cheerful song for him. He asks them one last time, and the First Musician flatly refuses, showing their indifference to the tragic situation in the house.

speaker: FIRST MUSICIAN
content: The musician refuses to play, stating simply, "No." This blunt refusal highlights the disconnect between the musicians' practical concerns and the household's overwhelming grief over Juliet's apparent death. They see a canceled gig, while the Capulets are in mourning.

speaker: PETER
content: Peter is threatening to beat the musicians for their disrespectful jokes about Juliet's "death." When the First Musician misunderstands and asks what he will give them, he is taking the word "give" literally, expecting a tip rather than a beating. This creates a moment of dark comedy through the misunderstanding.

speaker: FIRST MUSICIAN
content: The First Musician is asking for payment, since the wedding celebration has turned into a funeral and their services are no longer needed. This highlights the sudden shift from joy to tragedy and the practical, mercenary concerns of the working-class characters, contrasting with the intense emotions of the nobles.

speaker: PETER
content: Peter sarcastically refuses to pay the musicians, saying he'll only give them mockery ("the gleek") and then insults them by calling one a "minstrel." The First Musician retorts by insulting Peter back, calling him a lowly "serving-creature." This quick exchange of insults shows the servants' dark humor and highlights the jarring contrast between the tragedy unfolding upstairs and the petty squabbling below.

speaker: FIRST MUSICIAN
content: The musician is refusing to pay Peter, the Nurse's servant, for a song. He uses the insulting term "serving-creature" to belittle Peter and dismiss his request, showing the musicians' cynical and mercenary attitude amidst the household's grief over Juliet's apparent death.

speaker: PETER
content: Peter threatens to hit the First Musician with a kitchen knife, declaring he won't tolerate their "crotchets" (puns on musical notes/quarrelsome ideas). The musicians cleverly turn his musical puns back on him, with the Second Musician dryly advising him to put away both his weapon and his attempted wit.

speaker: FIRST MUSICIAN
content: The musician is punning on musical notes ("re," "fa") to complain that the Nurse is dismissing them without pay. He means she is "noting" them—writing them down as debtors—instead of paying them for their services. This dark humor contrasts with the tragic scene of Juliet's apparent death.

speaker: SECOND MUSICIAN
content: The Second Musician is telling Peter to stop threatening them with his dagger and to stop trying to be clever. He is responding to Peter's aggressive and sarcastic behavior by asking him to calm down and cease his foolish banter.

speaker: PETER
content: Peter, a servant, is angrily challenging the musicians with wordplay instead of actual violence. He sarcastically quotes a ballad about music's soothing power to mock them for playing cheerful tunes at a time of grief. His question about "silver sound" is a taunt, implying their music is worthless and out of place.

speaker: FIRST MUSICIAN
content: The musician is explaining why the instrument called a "silver sound" is so named; "silver" here refers to the metal used in the instrument's construction, which produces a pleasing, clear tone. He is making a simple, literal pun to answer Peter's question, highlighting the musician's practical, unemotional perspective amidst the household's grief over Juliet's apparent death.

speaker: PETER
content: Peter rudely dismisses the musicians' earlier conversation as idle chatter ("prates"). He then directly challenges the Second Musician, Hugh Rebeck, to explain his earlier comment about "silver sound." The musician's reply is a cynical pun, stating that musicians play their instruments ("sound") in order to get paid ("for silver").

speaker: SECOND MUSICIAN
content: The Second Musician makes a pun on the word "silver," explaining that musicians play for money ("silver") as well as for the "silver sound" of their instruments. This cynical joke highlights the professional reality of the musicians, who are now out of a job because the wedding feast has been canceled due to Juliet's apparent death.

speaker: PETER
content: Peter sarcastically addresses the musician James Soundpost, calling his words meaningless chatter. This highlights the servants' cynical, detached reaction to the noble household's grief over Juliet's apparent death, contrasting their practical concerns with the family's emotional turmoil.

speaker: THIRD MUSICIAN
content: The musician is expressing confusion and helplessness, admitting he has no idea how to respond to the chaotic situation. His remark highlights the stark contrast between the household's grief over Juliet's apparent death and the musicians' practical, detached perspective.

speaker: PETER
content: Peter sarcastically tells the musicians they can only afford "silver sound" because they are too poor for gold. He then quotes a line from a popular song, twisting its meaning to mock their financial state and dismiss their request for payment.

speaker: FIRST MUSICIAN
content: The musician is complaining about Peter, who just rudely insulted them and refused to pay for their services. He's calling Peter a "pestilent knave," meaning an annoying and contemptible low-born man. This exchange provides a moment of comic relief and a cynical, practical perspective on death, contrasting with the family's tragic grief over Juliet's supposed corpse.

speaker: SECOND MUSICIAN
content: The Second Musician dismisses the absent Peter with a curse, telling his companions they should go inside the Capulet house to wait for the funeral party and then stay for the meal. This brief exchange highlights the practical, almost indifferent attitude of the working-class characters, providing a moment of dark comic relief amidst the tragic discovery of Juliet's "death."

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo is expressing a buoyant, hopeful mood, believing his pleasant dream foretells good news. He dreamed that Juliet kissed him back to life, making him feel like an emperor. This joyful feeling from a mere dream makes him reflect on how much richer real love must be.

speaker: BALTHASAR
content: Balthasar mistakenly believes Juliet is dead and tells Romeo her body rests in the Capulet tomb while her soul is in heaven. He explains he witnessed her burial and rode quickly to bring this news, apologizing for delivering it since Romeo assigned him this duty.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo has just learned of Juliet's supposed death from Balthasar. He immediately rejects his predetermined fate ("defy you, stars") and decides to take immediate action. He orders Balthasar to fetch writing materials and horses so he can return to Verona tonight.

speaker: BALTHASAR
content: Balthasar urges Romeo to calm down because his pale, frantic appearance suggests something terrible has happened. "Import/Some misadventure" means his expression indicates a disastrous event—Balthasar knows Juliet is "dead" but hasn't yet revealed this news directly.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo dismisses Balthasar's mistaken belief that Juliet is dead, insisting he is wrong and commanding him to leave. He then urgently asks if the Friar has sent any letters, revealing his desperate hope for news from Verona.

speaker: BALTHASAR
content: Balthasar is respectfully telling Romeo that he will not leave him alone in Mantua. He feels loyalty and concern for his master, especially since Romeo appears distressed. This sets up Balthasar’s presence for the crucial news he is about to deliver.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo dismisses Balthasar's concerns and orders him to leave immediately to hire horses for their journey. He promises to follow shortly, showing his urgent determination to reach Juliet's tomb.

speaker: APOTHECARY
content: The Apothecary responds to Romeo's loud knocking at his door, establishing the setting and introducing the character. This brief line immediately creates tension and sets up the illegal transaction that follows.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo offers the Apothecary a large sum of money—forty ducats—to buy a powerful, fast-acting poison. He describes it as a substance that will spread instantly through the veins, causing the "life-weary taker" to die as quickly as gunpowder explodes from a cannon. The Apothecary hesitates, noting that selling such deadly drugs is punishable by death in Mantua.

speaker: APOTHECARY
content: The Apothecary is telling Romeo that he does possess deadly poisons, but selling them is a capital offense under Mantua's law. This hesitation establishes the stakes for the transaction, making Romeo's subsequent bribe more urgent and morally significant.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo is trying to convince the impoverished Apothecary to sell him poison, which is illegal. He argues that the Apotheary's desperate, starving appearance shows he has nothing to lose from breaking the law, since the world offers him no lawful way to escape his poverty. In response, the Apothecary agrees, stating that only his extreme need, and not his personal desire, makes him consent to the illegal act.

speaker: APOTHECARY
content: The Apothecary is stating that his desperate financial situation forces him to sell Romeo the illegal poison, even though his conscience objects to the transaction. This highlights the moral conflict between his ethical will and his physical need, making him a reluctant accomplice in the tragedy.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo is paying the Apothecary for the poison, acknowledging that he is exploiting the man's desperate poverty rather than his willingness to sell an illegal substance. The Apotheecary then gives him instructions, warning that the poison is so potent it would kill even a man with the strength of twenty.

speaker: APOTHECARY
content: The Apothecary is giving Romeo instructions for using the poison he has just sold him. He explains that the substance is lethal enough to kill twenty men at once, emphasizing its immediate and overwhelming potency. This underscores the finality of Romeo's desperate plan to join Juliet in death.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo is paying the Apothecary for poison, but he claims that money itself is a more destructive poison in society than the actual toxic compounds. He tells the Apothecary to use the gold to buy food and improve his health. Finally, Romeo renames the poison a "cordial," or restorative drink, because he intends to use it to join Juliet in death, which he sees as a welcome release.

speaker: FRIAR JOHN
content: Friar John is urgently calling out for Friar Laurence. His tone suggests he has important news, likely about the failed delivery of Friar Laurence's letter to Romeo, which will lead to the tragic misunderstanding in the final act.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: Friar Lawrence recognizes Friar John's voice and immediately asks for news from Romeo in Mantua. He urgently wants to know Romeo's response to his letter explaining Juliet's fake death, or to read the letter itself if Romeo wrote one. This shows his anxiety about whether his plan has been successfully communicated.

speaker: FRIAR JOHN
content: Friar John explains that he was quarantined by health officials who suspected he and another friar had been in a plague-infected house. This prevented him from delivering Friar Laurence's letter to Romeo in Mantua, which sets up the tragic misunderstanding to follow.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: Friar Lawrence is urgently asking who delivered his letter to Romeo, since Romeo should have known about Juliet's fake death but instead came to the tomb believing she was truly dead. This question reveals that the letter never reached Romeo, creating the tragic misunderstanding that will lead to both lovers' deaths.

speaker: FRIAR JOHN
content: Friar John explains to Friar Laurence that he failed to deliver the letter to Romeo. Due to a plague outbreak, the authorities quarantined him and he couldn't find another messenger willing to risk exposure. This crucial failure means Romeo remains unaware of Juliet's fake death, setting the stage for tragedy.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: Friar Lawrence realizes with alarm that the undelivered letter was critically important, not trivial, and its failure to reach Romeo could lead to disastrous consequences. He urgently sends Friar John to fetch a crowbar so he can personally retrieve Juliet from the tomb before she wakes, hoping to prevent the tragedy he now fears is imminent.

speaker: FRIAR JOHN
content: Friar John is speaking to Friar Laurence, agreeing to fetch something for him. This brief line shows his willingness to assist, but the audience knows he is about to fail in his crucial mission to deliver Friar Laurence's letter to Romeo, setting up the tragic conclusion.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: Friar Lawrence must go alone to the Capulet tomb because Juliet will awaken soon. He worries she will be angry that Romeo was not informed of their plan, so he intends to hide her in his cell while sending another letter to Mantua. The final line vividly describes Juliet as a living person trapped in a burial vault meant for the dead.

speaker: PARIS
content: Paris orders his page to extinguish the torch and hide by a yew tree, listening for footsteps so he can whistle a warning—this shows Paris is secretly visiting Juliet’s tomb and fears being discovered. The page’s aside reveals his fear of the churchyard but also his loyalty, as he resolves to obey despite his unease.

speaker: PAGE
content: The Page admits his fear of being alone in the graveyard but resolves to take the risk anyway. His brief moment of bravery is crucial, as he stays to witness the tragic events that follow.

speaker: PARIS
content: Paris is mourning at Juliet's tomb, believing her to be truly dead. He vows to visit nightly to decorate her grave with flowers and weep for her, performing these rituals as a tribute to his lost love. When his page whistles a warning, Paris hides, fearing that any intruder would disrespect his private mourning ceremony.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo orders Balthasar to hand over tools to break into the Capulet tomb, then gives him a letter for Montague. He commands Balthasar to leave and not return, threatening violent dismemberment if he disobeys, explaining his savage intent is driven by the need to see Juliet and retrieve a ring.

speaker: BALTHASAR
content: Balthasar is telling Romeo he will leave and not bother him further. He says this because Romeo has just threatened him with death if he stays to watch what happens at the tomb. This line shows Balthasar's obedience and fear, but he secretly disobeys by hiding nearby to watch over his master.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo is speaking to Balthasar, his servant, whom he has just paid. He gives him money ("Take thou that") as a gesture of friendship and to ensure his loyalty. He then orders Balthasar to leave him alone at the tomb, wishing him a good life so that he will not interfere with Romeo's plan to kill himself.

speaker: BALTHASAR
